text: A large, black, powerful-looking motorcycle waits propped on its center stand on the gravel shoulder of a deserted country road. The gold lettering on its tank and side cov identifies it as a Norton Commando 850. Two white Bell full-coverage helmets sit on its saddle, l medieval jousting helmets. Beyond the motorcycle, stretched out on a grassy rise, li Hart Read, twenty-six, and his long-time girlfriend Rose, who is the kind of eighteen that often seems more like fifteen, and once in a while like twelve. At the moment Rose is definitely eighteen and in control things, producing tuna sandwiches with lettuce and mayonn out of a string bag and pouring coffee, pre-mixed with su and milk, from a small thermos flask. Read watches her pl housewife with vast amusement. Rose holds out a sandwich.
What've we got, Rose? Steak on a bun?
Tuna with lettuce and mayo. You gonna make trouble?
Yeah. Big trouble. He grabs Rose's wrist and pulls her close. He looks her d in the eyes.
I want steak. Read kisses her full on the mouth. Rose drops the sandwic into the grass.
Steak. They kiss passionately.

Read kicks the big Norton into life. Rose puts on her hel does up the chin strap, and gets on the machine behind R Read waits for her to get settled, blips the throttle, th accelerates off the shoulder of the road, fishtailing sli in the gravel.

The Norton booms along the twisty two-lane road. The road clear and Read feels good. He opens the throttle even mor almost becoming airborne over the crest of a steep rise, leaning the bike over in the corners until he scrapes rub off the footpegs. Rose rides loose, completely at ease behind Read. She cla her arms around him loosely, always going with the motion the machine, closing her eyes in pleasure.

Further up the road, a neat white VW pop-top camper trund along in the opposite direction carrying a middle-aged ma his wife, and their twelve-year-old daughter. They are ci slickers out for an autumn camping jaunt, and things are going well for them.
(scrutinizing crumpled map) We passed it.
We didn't pass it. I remember that farm.
We passed it. That farm comes after concession road 12 and we were supposed to turn at concession road 11.
I don't remember that farm, Dad.
We didn't pass it. I very distinctly remember that farm.
If you would just stop this vehicle  long enough to take a look at the map I will prove to you beyond any shadow of a doubt that we...

(losing his temper) All right! The man swings the camper across both lanes in one furiou motion and slams on the brakes just before they go over t edge of the road into a ditch bordering an open field.

You're both right and I'm all wrong. He slams the camper into reverse and backs up as far as h can, then slams it into first and lurches forward, trying vainly to make a clean three-point turn on the narrow roa
We'll turn around and go all the way back. When the camper is stretched completely across both lanes the highway, it stalls. The man twists the key viciously it won't restart.
Goddamn thing! Shoulda never sold the goddamn station wagon.
The station wagon used to use too much gas, remember, Dad?
You keep quiet when your dad's ina sweat, Valerie.

(still trying to start the camper) Goddamn thing. Shoulda never sold the wagon. Without warning, Read's bike suddenly appears over the cr of the hill just beyond the camper. The bike is nearing 1 miles an hour. The wife sees it first.
Oh, Christ, Bob!

(looking up) Huh? Oh, Christ! There is no place for Read to go except off the road. The bike shoots over the drainage ditch beside the road two f from the nose of the camper. The man and his wife sit wit their mouths open, watching through their front windshiel the bike fly through the air into an overgrown field, as though it were happening on TV.

When the bike finally lands in the field, it hits down fr wheel first. The impact slams Read over the handlebars in the trunk of a small but solid tree. Rose stays with the machine for one complete cartwheel. The motorcycle ends u on top of her, the tank across her belly. Before she can move, the tank explodes into flames. The flames begin to melt the plastic visor of her helmet.

The camper driver turns around in his seat and starts to rummage around, looking for something to put out the fire His wife gets hysterical. She can see Rose trying vainly get out from under the bike.
Oh, my God! She's gonna burn! She's gonna die!
Where's the kid's blanket? Where's the kid's goddamn blanket!?
Jackie, a cool blonde English woman in her early forties has been bird-watching from the clinic's terrace. Somethi startling attracts her attention.

I don't believe it. Lloyd Walsh, an actor in his late thirties in the Keloid Clinic of Cosmetic Surgery for his second facial touch-u pauses in the middle of a sit-up which he is performing o an exercise mat a few yards away. Walsh is wearing a blue jogging outfit whose top bears the words 'JOGGING KILLS.' His head is bandaged.
What is it? You spot a rare tufted tit-mouse or somethin'? Jackie turns away from her binoculars. She has thin surgi wires attached to the upper and lower eyelids of both eye
There's a motorcycle burning in the middle of a field. I think there's somebody under it. Walsh jumps to his feet with exaggerated athletic vigor.
Yeah? Lemme have a look. Jackie hands Walsh her binoculars and points him in the r general direction.
See that column of smoke? Just follow it down to its source. We look through the binoculars with him as he does so. Su enough, there is a bike burning in a field with someone trapped beneath it.
Wow. Lookit that! He turns and begins to sprint for the stairway at the end the terrace.
Where are you going?
Gonna tell the boys downstairs. It's right up their alley.
Oh.  (calling after the disappearing Walsh) Careful with my binoculars! They're very expensive!

The three partners who own and operate the Keloid Clinic holding an informal meeting in the posh boardroom of the clinic, with cigars (Cypher), cigarettes, coffee, and ful ashtrays much in evidence. Involved are Dr. Daniel Keloid, a youthful forty-five, lo key but forceful, founder of the Keloid Clinic and extrem successful society plastic surgeon; Keloid's wife, Roxann who is herself an MD and who was once a student of Keloid and Murray Cypher, the clinic's accountant. Cypher is for eight, dapper, generally enthusiastic, and believes passionately in creative accounting. It has apparently been a long and tiring session. Cypher particular shows signs of strain. His end of the table is littered with pages of scratch pad covered with hastily scrawled notes and figures.

As far as I'm concerned these guys are completely legit. The bank is just as convinced as I am. They told me they're willing to go all the way with us. I'm telling you, Danny -- a franchise operation for plastic surgery resorts is one of those magnificent, inevitable ideas.

Banks are always quick to say that when everything's rolling easy. But you can take it from me -- first sign of heat from the medical association, first cries of professional outrage, and the bank'll call back its note and leave us hanging by our thumbs.
It's not the financing that's bothering you, Dan. Your voice has that edge to it.
I've never denied it. I sure as hell don't want to become the Colonel Sanders of plastic surgery.
Why not? Sounds great to me.
I'll tell you why not. Because it's unprofessional, unmedical, and unsavory.
You thought of it.
I was only kidding.
You were not. Besides, you want me to go back and tell three of the largest investment groups in North America, 'Forget it. He was only kidding?!

(in only partially mock despair) Oh, God. It's all gotten out of hand. I can see it now: fifty enfranchised Keloid's Cosmetic Surgery Clinics flung across the face of North America like Holiday Inns. Next thing you know, Do-It-Yourself Facelift Kits.
I like it. We could call it... we could call it Suture Self. (starts to scribble madly) No, I'm serious. I like that. There's got to be a way.
All right, boys. I think we're getting a bit silly...  The office intercom on the table chimes and the voice of Steve, an orderly, fills the room.
Is Dr. Keloid there? It's urgent.
Yeah, what is it, Steve?
There's been a motorcycle accident a few minutes down the highway here. Looks like a couple of people have been hurt. Should I take the van and go get 'em?
Yeah, sure. (short pause) Hey, wait a minute. Steve? You still there?
Yeah.
Hang on till I get there, OK? I'm coming with you. Meet you at the garage.
Roger. The intercom chimes off as Keloid stands up to leave. Cyp throws his pen on the table.
(exasperated) Oh, now, Dan. We've got a lot of decisions to make...
(leaving) You and Murray work it out, hon. Just make the pill easy for me to swallow, OK? He closes the door behind him, leaving Cypher and Roxanne their own devices.
Well, what do you think about facelift kits, Roxy? I mean, they've got abortion kits.
(frustrated) Let's just forget that anybody ever mentioned the idea, OK, Murray? Cypher shrugs. It still sounds great to him.

In the middle of a landscaped triangle of lawn stands a l light-box-style sign which reads KELOID CLINIC OF COSMETI SURGERY. Along one side of the triangle runs a crushed-gr driveway at the end of which is a long, low garage just b the main building, which looks as though it might once ha been a small stable. One of the three doors of the garage slides up and a van peels rubber out of the garage, sliding a bit once it hit the gravel. The van is set up inside and out exactly like standard big-city ambulance, but without any ambulance markings. Instead, sedate white lettering on the doors re KELOID CLINIC, LTD.

Read lies crumpled at the base of the tree. The end of hi right collarbone is sticking out at a bizarre angle and h right shoulder is hanging too low. Read has regained enou consciousness to feebly undo his helmet with his left han Beyond him, clouds of oily black smoke curl skywards from the fallen Norton. Read can hardly focus his eyes on the figures running toward them from the camper at the edge o the field. He slips dreamily into unconsciousness.

The clinic van turns off a secondary road on to the two-l highway and accelerates furiously, tossing its occupants around as it momentarily slews sideways. In the back of the van are Steve, who is busily preparing stretchers and oxygen, and Dr. Keloid. Keloid prepares several hypodermic syringes while expert bracing himself against the motion of the van. Steve finishes attaching a hose to a small cylinder of ox and turns the release valve to test the oxygen flow throu the nose-piece.

Well, we've got oxygen now, Dr. Keloid. Keloid watches the thin column of black smoke looming lar through the windshield of the van. He reaches for a small fire extinguisher affixed to the frame of the van and beg to undo the clamps holding it there.
I think we're going to have to use this before we get close enough for the oxygen, Steve.

Rose has stopped moving under the flaming machine. The ma from the camper, running and stumbling over the uneven gr finally arrives, followed by his older son (who is about thirteen). The man tries vainly to smother the flames wit his younger son's blanket, but the heat is too intense fo him to get really close. The man is almost in tears with horror and frustration. H son just stares wide-eyed.

The clinic van bounces to a halt by the edge of the field and the driver, the most junior of the clinic's four orderlies, jumps out and runs around to the back of the v The back doors swing open and Keloid jumps out with the f extinguisher in one hand and a small leather bag in the o He heads for the flames as the wife and her kid watch fro the front seats of the camper. The wife sticks her head o of the window and points at the flames.
(to Keloid) They're over there, Doctor! They  were speeding! Keloid is soon followed by the two orderlies carrying a l wheeled stretcher, which they have hauled from the back o the van.

The man who was driving the camper is still making sporad attempts to beat out the flames with the blanket when Kel arrives and opens up the valve of the fire extinguisher. white powdery foam covers everything in a few seconds, ki the flames easily.

(to Keloid) I tried to put it out. I couldn't get near it. Keloid kneels beside Rose. He takes a pair of scissors fr his bag and cuts the helmet strap under her chin. He slip the helmet off her head with great care. Her long blonde hair falls into a pool around her face, which seems remar at peace and untouched: only a rectangle of black soot wh her helmet's visor melted away and admitted smoke gives a indication of what she's gone through. When the orderlies arrive, the man points out Read for th
There's another one over there. I saw him movin' around a minute ago.

(to orderlies) Might as well go get him. We won't be ready to move her for a few minutes. The orderlies trot off toward Read with their stretcher. man watches them leave, then turns back to look at Rose. shakes his head as Keloid gives her an injection.
Christ. I didn't know it was a girl. Is she dead?

This isn't embalming fluid I'm  shooting into her. See if you can lift the machine off her. Use the blanket around your hands. It's hot. The man wraps the blanket around his hands and begins to half-pull, half-slide the Norton off Rose by the handleba The orderlies go by on their way to the van with Read unconscious on the stretcher. As the bike slides away to reveal Rose's abdomen, the man recoils in horror.
My God.
The clinic van speeds along the road toward the clinic.

Rose is on the stretcher with intravenous tubes in her ar bottles hanging over her head, an oxygen mask over her mo and nose, and several layers of blood-soaked bandages and surgical gauze over her abdomen. The senior orderly monit the oxygen flow, the IV levels, and Rose's pulse, while K speaks to someone at the clinic over the van's CB radio, which has a telephone-style speaker/ receiver. Read sits jammed into a small seat behind the driver, his head back against the van wall, completely dazed. He is conscious enough to wince in pain with every bump the van hits, but he obviously doesn't know where he is or why he there.

Roxanne? Yeah, listen. We're going to have to throw in everything we've got. I know, but let me tell you what we're looking at. The gas tank exploded over the girl's abdomen and I don't know what she's got left in there. The man's got a broken hand, separated shoulder, concussion, the usual. We can send him to the General. But it's definitely major surgery for her, and right now. I know we're not, but we've got no choice. I'd say she's got a half hour to live  and it's three hours to the nearest serious hospital. It's us or nobody. Yeah. I hope I can remember too. Well, they say it's like riding a bicycle.

The van stops in front of the clinic and the orderlies ju out. Keloid holds the bottles and the oxygen as the order unload the stretcher and roll it up the front walk of the clinic, which is a spectacularly renovated old farmhouse all sandblasted auburn brick, pine, and cedar planking, w paint and Vista Vision windows. A group composed of patients and staff cluster around the main doors of the clinic to watch as the stretcher approa Nobody seems to notice Read, who has been left sitting in the van.

Lloyd Walsh holds open one of the main glass doors while nurse opens the other one. The secretary -- receptionist abandons her phones and her sleek plastic desk/filing cab module to work her way through the group at the doors in order to take a look. Walsh makes room for the secretary -- Sheila -- beside hi Rose is wheeled through the doors. Her condition is so obviously serious and so different from the usual 'touch- jobs done at the Keloid Clinic, which has a carefully calculated country resort atmosphere about it, that every becomes completely silent as she enters.
(to nurse at door) Get the guy in the van into observation and check him out. But take it easy -- concussion, separated shoulder, broken hand. OK, Louise? Maybe some Demerol when he becomes lucid.

OK, Dr. Keloid. Louise leaves the door once the stretcher has gone by and  heads out to the van. Walsh lets go of his door and jogs after her. Jackie, still wearing sunglasses, shakes her head as she watches the stretcher go off down the hall and turns to t middle-aged lady standing next to her.
What a waste. She doesn't even need a nose job.

The orderlies wheel the stretcher down a hallway which wa patently never meant to be used as a hospital corridor: R is getting a very rough ride. As they move along they pas various patients who react with shock and horror when the see Rose. The Keloid Clinic is usually more discreet abou blood than a normal hospital.
(as Rose passes) Jesus wept! What's that all about?
Somebody said something about an accident.

(repulsed) Couldn't they throw a sheet over it or something? I'm starting to feel like I'm in a hospital. The fastidious man and his companion go through some door which, according to an elegantly lettered sign on a wall lead to a squash court. The orderlies stop in front of another set of doors. Kelo hands one of them the bottles he has been holding as a se nurse, Rita, comes out to meet them. Rita is a very solid square-bodied, fortyish lady.
OK, boys. Take her into pre-op and tell Dr. Karl to set her up for the works.

Keloid and Roxanne wash with disinfectant in preparation Rose's operation, aided by a third orderly whom we have n seen before. Roxanne is short, dark, intense, and ambitious beyond her present practice. She does not wear her thirty-seven year particularly well, so the age difference between her and husband seems more theoretical than anything else. She is very particular about being called by her maiden name and known as Dr. Rushton to all the clinic's patients. At the moment, Keloid and Roxanne are having a very controlled, key argument which Roxanne tries to keep the orderly from hearing.
I don't buy it, Dan.
You haven't seen her.
I don't have to see her. Neutral field grafts have never been used internally. We could end up with a terminal cancer patient on our hands.

Aw, c'mon. We can monitor, Roxy. She's got nothing to lose. Literally. She doesn't have enough small intestine left to absorb nutrient. If we just close her up she'll have to be fed intravenously for the rest of her life, which will be a short and a dismal one. But if we graft neutral field tissue cones into the abdominal cavity, there's a chance that they'll read her condition by post-embryonic induction and develop into a new set of intestines.

Or run wild and make some very creative malignant tumors. Dan, the clinic doesn't need this. Let's play it safe. Keloid doesn't respond. He finishes snapping on his surgi gloves and turns to the scrub-nurse, who helps him on wi his sterilized operating tunic.

Read has regained full consciousness in the clinic's observation room and is watching Louise cut away his well worn leather motorcycle jacket with a pair of snub-nosed surgical scissors. She cuts her way up the right sleeve t the shoulder, then across the shoulder to the collar. She then able to slip the jacket easily away from Read's righ shoulder, which is still very obviously not where it shou be. She now starts in on his Norton T-shirt, which is all was wearing underneath his jacket.
Oh, no. Not the T-shirt. Rose gave me the T-shirt.
I think you'd find it pretty painful trying to take if off the standard way. Read makes an attempt to slip his arm out of his T-shirt immediately gives up, grimacing in pain.
No, look. I think I can... Ow! Oh! You're right. Cut the thing off. I'll put it up on the wall of my garage. Louise continues snipping off the T-shirt.
So when do I get to see Rose?
Not for a while.
Why not? Louise doesn't answer. Read pulls away from Louise and tries to stand up. He can keep his balance and falls back against the wall, banging his wrecked shoulder.
I want to see her right now! Ow! Oh, God. I didn't kill her, did I? Louise reaches for a syringe of Demerol.
She's not dead.
What is that stuff? I don't want you to put me out.
It's just Demerol. It'll ease the pain. All right? Read lets Louise take his good arm. She swabs him down an sinks the needle in.
(sarcastically) Sure. Wonderful. Anything to ease the pain.

Keloid and Roxanne are well into their operation on Rose, assisted by a team of five which includes Dr. William Kar the clinic's anesthetist. Keloid and Roxanne are in the process of cutting large squares of skin from Rose's thig

Now, I know everyone here is familiar with the standard techniques of skin grafting, but what we're going to do is a little out of the ordinary. I'll explain it as we go. We're removing full-thickness skin grafting material from the patient's thighs as per normal graft acquisition procedure. However, before these grafts are applied to the damaged areas of the patient's breasts, abdomen, and so on, they will be treated so that they become morphogenetically neutral. They are then called neutral field grafts.
Can we treat the graft material here, Dr. Keloid?

No, Dr. Karl. The graft tissue will be frozen and sent to the Sperling Institute. We'll have to keep the patient in an operation-ready state until it comes back to us. That's going to be a bit trying for all of us, but it can't be helped. As Keloid speaks, the sections of thigh skin are placed i spun aluminum cylinders of the same general type as those used in eye banks. The cylinders are then sealed and plac in a medical freezer.
I don't understand the functional difference between neutral field and normal graft tissue, Doctor.

Well, when the thigh skin tissue is treated, Nurse Benedetto, it'll lose its specificity as both thigh tissue and skin tissue. For example, if it were grafted to a burned cheek, it wouldn't just be thigh skin with the color and texture of thigh skin -- it would actually develop as facial tissue. In other words, neutral field tissue has the same ability to form any part of the human body that the tissue of a human embryo has.
Doctor, this patient has lost most of her absorptive intestinal mucosa. Could neutral field tissue reconstruct an organ as complex as the small intestine.
Yes, Dr. Karl. I think that under the right circumstances it could. I've done it myself using lab animals  at the Sperling Institute. Keloid and Roxanne exchange glances, then Keloid looks aw

Let me add that there is always a possibility that carcinomas will form when neutral field grafts are used internally. In this case, we're using a radical plastic-surgery technique to compensate for our lack of heavy medical hardware. We're doing it to save a life. It's the only trick we've got.
Wide shot of exterior front of the Keloid Clinic in late autumn.
Same shot as previous scene, one month later. Snow is on ground and the trees are bare.

location: ROSE'S ROOM AT THE KELOID CLINIC

text: Read stands over Rose's bed, which is a very well-disguis hospital bed (everything possible is done to keep the cli from feeling like a hospital). Read's left hand is encase in a wire cage which supports all his fingers. He is watc Rose intently, who is still in a coma and is attached to battery of intravenous bottles connected to her by clear vinyl tubes and IV needles. Read is particularly fascinat by Rose's eyes, which he can see moving around wildly beh her eyelids. He bends close, then kisses her gently on her pale, dry l

Nurse Louise walks briskly down a hall toward Rose's room On her way she passes Judy Glasberg clutching a pocket ed of The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud and strolling thoughtfully in the opposite direction.
Hi, Judy Glasberg. You back again?

Daddy didn't think the new nose was different enough, so I'm in for more alterations. I keep telling him it looks just like his, and he keeps saying, 'That's why I want you to change it.' I'm terrified to find out what it all means. They both laugh. The two women part and go their separate ways. We follow Louise as she opens the door to Rose's room, which bears printed sign saying: INTENSIVE CARE, QUALIFIED PERSONNEL ONLY.
Louise enters the room in time to surprise Read in the ac of pulling back the sheet covering Rose.
Didn't you see the sign on the door, Mr Read? You're supposed to register with me before you come in here.

I saw it. I guess I consider myself qualified. Louise edges Read away from the bed and covers Rose up ag Her entire body is heavily bandaged, and almost every inc of exposed skin has an IV needle taped to it. Louise begi to moisten Rose's eyelids and lips with various gels.
What are you trying to do, give her pneumonia?
I'm trying to ease my guilt feelings by telling myself that Rose is getting better.
(softening) I see. Is it working?
Is she getting better?
You've been here often enough in the past two months to know as much as I do.
When do I get to see Dr. Keloid?
You never tell me in advance when you're coming. How can I make an appointment for you?
I never know in advance when the next wave of guilt will hit me. I want to see him right now.
He's in a meeting.
Tell him I forced you.
(leaving the room) All right. But please... no touching until she's conscious.
OK, Mom. Louise makes a face and leaves.

Read sits across from Keloid's desk in Keloid's office, w seems more like a successful PR executive's office than a doctor's. While they talk, Keloid toys with Rose's file, really ever looking at it: he is obviously very familiar with its contents, and also in a very distracted frame of mind.
Well, as you've seen, Rose is still in some kind of coma, sort of half real coma, half normal deep sleep. Could be weeks before she's lucid.
You don't know for sure?

No. Her body is still in a state of total shock. She can't possibly be moved to a city hospital yet. Her grafts seem to be healing well. We've been monitoring the internal grafts electronically and there is definitely new tissue growth happening in the abdominal cavity. Whether this growth will mature into functioning intestinal mucosa we won't know for quite a while.
You mean if your grafts or whatever they are don't work, she'll never eat like a normal human being again. She'll have to be fed intravenously.

That's right. At the moment, she has only enough small intestine to digest the most basic nutrient material. See -- the longer the small intestine, the more complex the food that can be broken down and absorbed by the body as food. Cows have lots and lots of intestines so they can eat grass and other vegetable matter. We have medium-length intestines, so we can eat meat and a limited variety of vegetable matter. Vampire bats -- the real ones, I mean -- have short intestines, so they eat whole blood, which is very easy to break down and assimilate. Your girlfriend's in the same boat.
What about her brain?
Her helmet probably saved her from brain damage, but until she's fully conscious...
You won't know that either.

(throwing up his hands) Hart, what can I tell you? There's no magic. Look, I've done my best. You're welcome to come here and keep your vigil by Rose's bedside any time the mood takes you, but please believe me, I will personally telephone you the instant Rose shows even the slightest signs of regaining consciousness. Read sighs, then shrugs with his good shoulder.
Lloyd Walsh and Read stand in the driveway watching as tw orderlies load the burned and smashed hulk of Read's Nort into the back of Murray Cypher's Ford station wagon.
Jeez, when I saw that thing burning, I never figured I'd be standing here talking to you a month later. How's your hand?

They're taking the cage off this afternoon. That's when I'll find out. The pin stays in my shoulder for another month, though. Doesn't seem to bother me except when it gets damp. Cypher comes hurriedly out of the front door, putting on suit jacket and stuffing papers into his attachГ‚В® case same time. He walks over to Read and Walsh and opens the door of his car.
(to Walsh) Hi, Lloyd. How ya doin'?
Great. Cypher gets into his car, slams the door, and pops the passenger door open for Read.
C'mon, Hart. I got a pack of hungry investors waiting for me. Read gets into the station wagon as the orderlies slam th rear door shut on the Norton. Walsh waves goodbye to Read who smiles weakly.

I hope you've got some friends who'll help you unload that pile of junk. I've got a bad back. What're you going to do with it? Use it for an ashtray? He turns the ignition key and starts the station wagon.

Giving it to a friend for parts. I can hardly stand to look at it. Think I'll get back into go-karts. Cypher laughs, waves to Walsh, and pulls away from the driveway. Walsh smiles at them and turns back to the clin patting himself absently under the chin as he goes.
Wide-angle shot of the front of the clinic as Walsh goes back inside.
Same shot as previous scene, but late at night. There are only one or two lights on inside.

The night nurse checks her watch at her station, which i little more than a desk, chair, and lamp placed at the en of a hall. It's time for her to make her rounds. She puts down her magazine -- People -- and walks down the hall. A the end of it, she disappears down a stairwell.
The night nurse walks past Rose's room, pausing only for moment to glance in at Rose's sleeping form. She then continues on down the hall.

The night nurse walks past Lloyd Walsh's door. There is a PLEASE DO NOT DISTURB sign hanging from his doorknob. The nurse notices that Walsh's light is on and diffusing out through the crack under the door, but she continues on do the hall.

Walsh is lying in bed reading The Life and Work of Sigmun Freud, which he has borrowed from Judy Glasberg. His room like all the private rooms at the clinic, is furnished in the style of the plushest, most modern jet-set ski lodges It's easy to understand why patients extend their stays b what is medically necessary, and just as obvious that the Keloid Clinic management makes no attempt to discourage t "home away from home' attitude toward the place. Walsh can't get comfortable with the book, which he has j started to read. He checks his watch. It's 1.13 a.m. He's little nervous about his operation tomorrow morning. He p down his book, gets out of bed, puts on his bathrobe, sli into his slippers, and leaves his room to go for a stroll through the deserted clinic.
Hands in pockets, Walsh strolls through the clinic, past lounge, the ping-pong table, the breakfast nook.

Walsh rounds a corner that leads him past Rose's door, wh still bears its INTENSIVE CARE sign. As he passes by her door, he hears a muffled scream followed by a series of m and indistinct, angry shouts. Walsh opens her door withou  hesitation.

By the light of the full moon and the hallway, Walsh can Rose thrashing around violently in her bed, getting twist up in her sheets and ripping out her IV needles. As he watches, one of her IV bottles, pulled off its stand by i feed tube, falls to the floor and smashes to pieces, spil blood plasma everywhere. Walsh now sees that the floor is littered with shredded b and pieces of surgical gauze and bandages, which Rose has torn from her various wounds and grafts. The plasma begin to soak into the debris surrounding the bed. Her torso is still covered only by bandages, making her look like a mu jerking to life in the half-light of her tomb. Walsh rushes over to the bed and quickly lowers the safet railing. He then tries to hold Rose down by the shoulders keep her from pulling out the last of her IV tubes. When grabs her by the wrists, he notices that she is oozing bl from where the IV needles have been pulled out.

Rosie, Rosie, sweetie, take it easy! You need that juice, sweetie. It's keeping you alive. Hey, easy, there. Easy. That's it. That's a girl. Under the pressure of Walsh's body, Rose begins to calm d Her eyes, which have been open but staring and unseeing, begin to fill with consciousness.
Hart? What are you... what are you doing, Hart? Are we all right? Are we...
I'm not Hart, Rosie. Hart's back in Montreal waiting for you. I'm Lloyd. I'm a friend of yours.
Hart?
Back in Montreal. Waiting for you.  He's fine. He's OK. I was just talking to him this afternoon.
Oh. I... I guess I was dreaming. Walsh lets go of Rose's wrists.
I don't think you were just dreaming. You and Hart were in a really spectacular motorcycle crash.
A crash? Was there fire? Was there... blood?
Yeah. Plenty of both. You're bleeding right now. (getting up) I'd better get Dr. Keloid. Rose grabs Walsh by the arm and pulls him back down on th bed.
No! Not yet. I'm all right. But I'm freezing cold, and you're so warm. Hold me.
Look, I think I'd better...
Please hold me. I'm dying of the cold. Rose puts her arms around Walsh, who hesitates for a mome then puts his arms around her and hugs her for a moment.
Oh, God, that feels so good. Behind Walsh's back, Rose pulls the last remaining IV nee out of her left wrist.
(a bit nervous)  Ah, look... you don't even know where you are, do you? Rose pulls Walsh's face down to hers, then slips her arms under his and locks her hands behind his back.
Sure I do. I'm here with you.
Look, this is really weird. Are you sure you know what you're... Ow! Feeling a sudden sharp pain, Walsh tries to pull away. Ro won't let him get up.

Hey, I think I... I think I cut myself or something. You got something sharp in there with you? Ow! Oh, that hurts! He makes a huge effort to lift himself off the bed, but R hangs on to him and comes up with him. Blood is soaking through Walsh's bathrobe around the right armpit, like da red sweat. He is moaning and sobbing as he strains to get away. Finally, Walsh collapses on top of Rose, quivering and whimpering. Rose sighs deeply and begins to stroke his he affectionately.

location: MISS OWEN'S ROOM AT THE CLINIC

text: Miss Beatrice Owen, a tough-looking maiden lady in her fifties, sits on the edge of her bed pulling on a pair of white gloves. She is wearing an immaculate morning outfit which looks vaguely '40s and probably is. One of her hand has been twisted by arthritis and puts up quite a struggl before allowing itself to be encased in its glove. She th begins to use her teeth to pull on the other glove. The second glove is only half-way on when Miss Owen hears desperate scratching and bumping at her door. She stops w she's doing.

Yes? (pause)  Who is it? After a pause comes more scratching, followed by the soun of a hand feebly slapping on the door. With her second gl still only half on, Miss Owen gets up, goes to the door, opens it. The instant the door is opened, a ghastly pale Lloyd Wals slumps heavily across Miss Owen's shoulders. The force dr her back several steps and she screams with fear.
Oh, God save us!

I'm sick. I'm sick. Help me. When she realizes she's not being attacked, Miss Owen ste back from Walsh, but, unsupported, he starts to fall to t floor. Miss Owen slips her hands up under his arms and gu him unsteadily to the bed.

Mr Walsh! What on earth has happened to you? Miss Owen sits Walsh on the bed, where he crumples into a awkward lying position. When she withdraws her hands from under his arms, Miss Owen finds that her right glove is soaking through with very watery blood.
I don't know. I can't remember a thing.

Keloid and Louise examine Walsh, who lies half-naked on h left side, his right arm stretched out over his head to e a deep, round, and still-bleeding puncture in his right armpit. Like everything else at the clinic, the examination room been designed and furnished with luxury and style in mind much as pure function. Even the cantilevered examination light which Keloid is playing on Walsh's wound is color- coordinated with the drapes, the chairs, the coat-rack, a the enamel finish of the examination table itself.
Were you sleepwalking? Could you have fallen against something outside and then come back in without waking up?
(voice still shaky) I doubt it. Never done anything like that before.
(to Louise) Get me some stuffing, maybe a sponge or two as well. This wound isn't clotting at all. I think we're going to have to shoot in some coagulants to get a scab to form.
Right away. She leaves, closing the door behind her. Keloid takes a c look at the wound through a large, illuminated magnifying glass.
From what I can see, it's a very very clean and precise wound. You haven't leaned on any picket fences, have you? Kind with those little spearheads?
(unable to respond to Keloid's attempt at humor) No. Keloid grunts, takes out a tongue depressor, and begins t probe Walsh's wound with it.
Does this hurt?
Can't feel a thing.
(surprised) You can't?
My whole right side has no feeling in it. Just this aching kind of tingling.
Hm. Louise comes in carrying wads of surgical gauze, sponges, etc. She puts them down and takes Keloid aside.
Dr Keloid? Kenny Kwong would like to see you.
Right now?
He says it's very important. He's waiting in the hall.

(confidentially) OK. Listen... our friend here may have had a stroke. I think the General's the best place for him. But before you plug him up I want 10 cc of blood drawn directly from that wound for tests. Then get Steve to drive him into the city in the ambulance. Tell him to take lots of plasma with him. We're going to have to forget about the coagulants until the General has a chance to do an ECG on him.
Will do, Doctor. Keloid leaves.
Keloid steps out into the hall and joins Kenny Kwong, the clinic's senior orderly, a concerned-looking, graying Chi  man of about fifty-five.
Can you come with me, please, Dr. Keloid?
Sure, Kenny. What's up? They begin to walk briskly down the hall, Kenny leading.
You told me to check around the grounds to see if I could find out how Mr. Walsh got hurt? Keloid nods.

I couldn't find nothing outside. No blood, nothing. Then Nurse Rita call me. She find something. She tell me go get Dr. Keloid. You see it, then you tell us what happened. They round the corner taking them into the hallway that g past Rose's room. Kenny walks up to Rose's door and knock sharply.
Nurse Rita waiting for you in here. After a short pause, Rita opens the door and ushers them inside, closing the door behind them.

Once inside the door, Keloid is shocked at the state of R room. It is basically as we last saw it, except that Rita has reattached Rose, who seems to be in a coma once again to her IV bottles. The area of the wall next to the doorhandle side of the d is smeared with bloody handprints -- Walsh apparently use the doorknob to pull himself to his feet, then supported himself by holding on to the wall and door moulding. Rita leads Keloid over to the bed, while Kwong hangs back watch that nobody enters inadvertently.

Watch your feet, Doctor. The police will probably want every little piece of glass and strip of gauze exactly the way we found it. Keloid finds a place to stand next to the bed, checks Ros eyes, then her pulse.
Why do you think the police would be interested in this, Rita?
Why, it's perfectly obvious that that Walsh fellow attempted to molest the poor girl while she was still in a coma. I've seen things like that happen before. Maybe he was drunk.
(drawing back the sheet) Hm. Her grafts have taken amazing well. Probably won't even have to rebandage. Hm. I can't even see any scar tissue. He lifts Rose's left arm and presses around her armpit.
Wow. I'll have to have a closer look at that.
Rejection problems? Keloid lowers her arm and covers her with the sheet again

(standing up) Don't think so. Seems to be an extreme swelling of the lymph nodes under the arm. Could just be a local infection that's under attack, but it's quite a bump. And there's some kind of lesion there. Doesn't seen to be gangrenous, but... He walks thoughtfully toward the door. Kwong stands wait
Want me to clean up the mess now, Doctor?
(snapping out of his train of thought) What? Oh, yes. But save all the pieces and scrape some of the dried blood on to a slide. Maybe we'll find something out.
But Dr. Keloid... Mr. Walsh, he may well be...

(turning to Rita) Rita, Lloyd Walsh wouldn't do something like that. He just wouldn't. And none of this explains how he got his wound. I think a quiet, thorough, and very private investigation is in order. Don't you? Rita lowers her eyes.
Wide-angle shot of the clinic in the dead of night. The m is full.
In the darkness of her room, Rose's eyes are open and sta She begins to pull the IV needles out of her wrists and ankles.

In the whirlpool room, which contains three full-size whirlpool baths, a bar, and a lounge, Judy Glasberg is ta a midnight whirlpool bath to calm herself down. The room deserted except for Judy, but she seems to have no troubl adjusting the controls of the bath to get it just right. As Judy plays with the temperature controls, the door be her opens and someone enters, closing the door behind her Judy looks up, startled. Rose stands at the door in her f clinic gown. For some reason, Judy suddenly feels vulnera in her skimpy bikini.
Rose? Is that you? I thought everyone was asleep. They told me you were still in a coma.

(approaching the edge of the bath) Oh, no. I'm doing much better now, thank you. She seems to be completely normal, and as childlike as ev save for the hollows under her eyes. Judy positions her b so that her nakedness is hidden by the swirling bubbles o the whirlpool.

It... it's really weird to meet you this way. I mean, I've never really talked to you before. But I sort of feel I know you, you've been around here for so long. And I saw them bring you in right after the accident.
Do you mind if I get in with you? I've been lying in bed for such a long time, my body aches all over.
Ah, well, I... does anybody know you're here? I mean, does Dr. Keloid know you... you've regained consciousness? Rose climbs into the bath with Judy, gown and all.

I don't think so. Everybody seemed to be asleep. It was a bit spooky waking up and finding myself all alone. I'm so glad I ran into you. (with surprise)  Hey, know what? I think I can feel the warmth of your body radiating out to me through the water. I've never felt anything like that before. Judy starts to grope for her towel by the side of the poo
I think I'd better get out now. I'm getting all wrinkly. Rose floats over to Judy and takes her by the arm, interf with Judy's attempt to get her towel.
Oh, no. Not yet. You haven't even told me your name.
Judy Glasberg. Nice to meet you. Rose slips her arms up under Judy's arms and hugs her tig
Mm. It's nice to meet you too. Judy tries to gently disengage herself from Rose's embrac
Oh, now, c'mon. You're embarrassing me. Let me put some clothes on and we'll have a few drinks or something,
When she realizes that Rose isn't going to let her go, Ju starts to struggle more seriously.

Let me go, please! I want to get dressed. Listen, to tell you the truth, I think there's still something wrong with you. I think you ought to let... Ow! Oh! Something's cutting me! Oh! It hurts! She starts to thrash about madly in the water, still lock in Rose's embrace. They dip under the water, then come up again, Judy gasping for air. Rose lets her move wherever wants, but keeps her arms locked about Judy, her hands no  digging into Judy's shoulders from behind. In tight close-up we see something joining the two bodies under the arms, from Rose's left to Judy's right. Even cl we see something fleshy slipping in and out of some kind sheath, barbs cutting through flesh, blood beginning to d along a fleshy translucent tube. From small glands at the base of the tube, dark green fluid, almost black, begins flow into the blood drawn up the tube. The mixture of blo and green fluid pumps back and forth in the tube. Judy is now moaning in spasms, her head arched back as fa away from Rose as possible, her hair floating in the wate behind her and forming spirals in the whirlpool. Rose holds on to Judy for dear life, her eyes closed in ecstasy, her cheeks unnaturally flushed. She doesn't noti that Judy's head is beginning to slip beneath the surface the water. Judy's body is wracked by one final spasm, the she relaxes completely, her head going under completely. last bubbles of air from her lungs mix with the bubbles s out by the whirlpool oxygenator. After a few moments, Ros releases Judy. We see a close-up of the translucent flesh tube, now empty of blood, sliding back into its sheath. It is only after she has backed away and taken several so deep breaths that Rose notices Judy's face is two inches below the surface of the water, the tip of her nose almos breaking through to the air but not quite. Rose frantical grabs Judy by the hair and pulls her out of the water. Ju isn't breathing. Rose manages to drag Judy to the edge of the pool, clambe out on to the side, then pulls Judy out on to the pool si with her, Judy trailing a thin trickle of blood in the wa behind her. Rose holds Judy's mouth open and tries to revive her usin mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, but it's no good. Judy is d Rose shakes her head and starts to cry.

Oh, no! No! Rose shakes Judy's corpse hysterically, then collapses ac it, sobbing. After a moment, she gets up, visibly fightin for control. She sets her jaw and begins to drag Judy's b out of the whirlpool room.

In the ramshackle garage behind the small house he has re in Montreal, Hart Read has finally gotten around to tryin to put his demolished Norton back together again. The eng has been removed from its frame and sits before him on a metal-topped work table, and Read is in the process of completely dismantling it. Small cardboard cartons of var sizes sit on the table, waiting to receive individual pie of the engine. The radio hung above the table is tuned to an FM rock sta which is on full blast, even though it is about 1 a.m.

In Read's kitchen, the telephone is ringing, but Read has chance of hearing it. Next to the phone, pinned to a cork message board with colored plastic drafting pins, are sev photos of Read and Rose enjoying happier times.
Rose listens to the phone ring at Read's from the telepho in the deserted main lounge. Her hair is wet and matted a she is shivering uncontrollably. She lets it ring, huddli in her chair.

Lloyd Walsh is in the process of pulling on his pants in observation ward of the General, which he shares with a thirtyish traffic-accident victim. Walsh's Lufthansa flig bag is already packed and ready to go, sitting on his bed the shadow of an IV blood plasma bottle.
Hey, you can't leave yet, Lloyd. They haven't figured out how come you're bleeding all over the place.
Aw, it's slowed down to a trickle. No problem.
How's your arm?
It's fine. He picks up his bag and opens the door without hesitation
If the night nurse comes around, I'll tell her you're in the can, how's that?
Terrific. Take care of yourself. He leaves, closing the door behind him.
Walsh walks briskly down a corridor which leads to the ma entrance of the Montreal General Hospital, flight bag in hand. Nobody stops him.

Walsh leaves the General and walks around the circular driveway to the street, where he is just in time to pick a cab being paid off by a night orderly arriving for work Walsh gets in the cab and it pulls away from the curb.
Walsh leans his head back against the back seat as the ca pulls away. He rolls his head from side to side, as thoug trying to shake off a headache.
The cab moves through the streets of Montreal and enters ramp leading eventually to the Decarie Expressway. The ca accelerates to the speed limit.
The nasal, wailing voice of a popular singer blares from four speakers in the cab. Walsh is now sitting quite stil in the back seat, head resting against the seat back.

Hey, Mister, you wanna sleep? I can turn the radio off. It's a long way  to Camelford. Walsh doesn't answer. The driver looks in his rear-view mirror. Walsh is slumped in the shadows of the back-seat area.

Hey, Mister. You want me to turn the radio off? Or maybe if you want I can turn off the back speakers and just leave on the front ones... He turns around in his seat to look at Walsh. His words d on his lips. Walsh is staring at him with eyes that have completely clouded over so that the whites of his eyes ar indistinguishable from the irises and pupils. Dark green foam is drooling from the corners of Walsh's mouth. The cab driver doesn't have a chance to react any further before Walsh attacks him viciously, grabbing him by the shoulders and biting the cab driver on the cheek.
The cab carrying Walsh veers crazily across three lanes o the nearly deserted expressway.
The cab driver tries madly to pull himself around in his seat so that he can see where he's going, screaming in pa all the while. With one tremendous jerk he frees his face from Walsh's locked jaws.

The cab finally slews completely out of control, smashes into the low concrete railing lining the expressway, cartwheels over the railing, and falls on to the expressw ramp some twenty feet below, where it is rammed by an imm diesel truck delivering furniture to a sub-urban warehous The cab is pushed fifty yards along the rampway, shedding pieces of bodywork and glass all the way, before the truc manages to stop.

location: THE KELOIDS' BEDROOM AT THE CLINIC

text: The telephone on the night table beside the Keloids' doub bed starts to ring. Dan Keloid rolls over, fumbles for t receiver, and finally gets it off the hook and up to his ear. Roxanne stirs beside him in bed.

Yeah. Yeah. No. No, you're kidding. Dead? Yeah. No, I would have absolutely no objections to an autopsy. It's definitely indicated. No, I've got nothing to add to my telephoned report. We never came up with anything else. Yeah. Right. OK. "Bye. He hangs up the phone in a state of drowsy excitement. Ro rolls over and puts her arm around him. Keloid picks up h wrist-watch to check the time. It's 3.07 a. m.
What is it, Dan?
Lloyd Walsh is dead. Roxanne starts to snap out of her sleep.
He's what?
He left the General about an hour ago. Told another patient he felt all right. He took a cab and the cab crashed on a highway. Both occupants dead.
Oh, God. Poor Lloyd. But you said something about an autopsy? Was the cab driver drinking?
No, it's Walsh. They're not happy with his corpse. (baffled) Something about the eyes... I'm going to have to go over Walsh's file again. It just doesn't add up.

By the light of a full moon, Rose walks purposefully down dirt country road, a borrowed windbreaker pulled tightly around her over her clinic gown and hospital slippers sta to come apart on her feet. She is determined to get as fa away from the clinic as she can by morning light.

Rose finds herself walking beside a moonlit field with a ramshackle barn at one end. She pauses beside the barn fo moment, then slips under the fence surrounding the field makes her way gingerly across the muddy barnyard toward t door of the barn. The house nearest the barn is dark. Ros gently edges open the door of the barn.

Once inside the barn, Rose feels around for a light switc She finds it without much trouble and flicks it on. The b is low and full of cobwebs, and houses only two solemn co and a scraggly chicken. Rose heads for the nest of straw that the two cows have m and gradually snuggles her way in between them. She starts to stroke the side of one of the cows, getting the animal accustomed to her touch, at the same time care slipping out of her windbreaker. She then raises her left arm and presses her left armpit flat against the cow's si After a pause, she gives a short, sharp push with her lef side, as though she's pushing something into the cow with her body. The cow responds by lifting up its head and tur to look at her. Satisfied that nothing too threatening is happening, it turns back and lowers its head again. Rose stretches out over the cow in ecstasy. Her eyes are closed. Blood begins to flow in a rapid, one-way stream f the cow into Rose. She is breathing rapidly and heavily. Suddenly, she pulls away from the cow, giving us a chance to see a flash of s kind of elongated, tube-like organ retracting under her l arm, dripping blood from its tip. As Rose lurches to her feet, we can see a small, deep wound leaking blood and gr bile-like fluid in the cow's side where Rose's armpit had been pressed. The cows stir in reaction to Rose's violen movement. She staggers away from the cows, dizzy and nauseous. She manages to reach the stalls, which she leans on for suppo before she begins to vomit. Suddenly, the door bangs open and a drunken old farmer stumbles into the barn, a whisky bottle in his hand.

All right, you! Hold it right there! (spotting Rose) Oh. Whatta we got here? Hello, sweet honey pie. What're ya drinkin'? You come in to get outta the cold? He waves the bottle at Rose as he approaches her, then pu his arm around her so that the bottle rests on her chest.

I got something ya can take a drink off of, an'it ain't no whisky, neither. He laughs coarsely and kisses Rose on the neck. When she fails to resist him, he drops his nearly empty whisky bot and starts to nuzzle her collarbone. Rose wearily slips h hand up behind the farmer's head and pulls it down toward her left armpit.

(surprised) Hey, that's real nice, honey pie. You like me, don't ya? I kin tell ya do. The farmer is slobbering happily around Rose's shoulder w she suddenly grabs his head by the hair with both her han and pulls him viciously down on the cutting points of her bloodsucking organ. The farmer screams in agony. Rose holds the farmer's head down until he stops screaming and starts breathing heavil spasmodically. Then she lets him go. The farmer straightens up. He is holding his hand over hi right eye. Rose is terrified at what she's done. With a horrified sob, she backs away, then turns and runs, stumb out the door, leaving the farmer to stand swaying in a s anesthetized stupor in the middle of the barn.

Read has fallen asleep at his kitchen table while working the engine of his Norton. The partially dismantled engine sits on a section of newspaper on the kitchen table next a half-empty cup of coffee and an open, grease-smeared No Owner's Manual. He is awakened out of his deep sleep by the sound of the kitchen phone ringing. Read jumps up, still half asleep, almost knocking over his chair in the process. It takes h a second or two to realize that he is in fact at home. Read grabs for the phone, somehow terrified that the pers on the other end will hang up before he answers.
Hello? (suddenly very excited) Rose? Is it really you? How come you're... I mean, the last time I Saw you... Oh, God. Rose, are you all right?

In the main lounge of the clinic, Rose kneels beside the table on which the lounge phone rests, cradling the recei in her hands. She is covered with blood, her gown has bee ripped, and she is close to hysteria. Her feet are covere with dirt and she's tracked mud inside, marking her trail from the clinic's back door clearly.
Hart? Oh, Hart. (sobbing) No, no, I'm not all right. I'm in terrible trouble. I want you to help me.
What are you talking about? Rosie, calm down, I can hardly understand what you're saying.
Hart, can you hear me?
I can hear you, Rosie.

Hart, you've got to come and get me. You've got to come and get me as fast as you can. She suddenly becomes aware of someone else's presence in lounge. She turns with a start. Rita, who is acting as ni nurse, is standing right behind her, a shocked and unbeli look on her face.

Rose, don't panic. Whatever's wrong I'll be able to help you, understand? Now, I can be at the clinic first thing in the morning, OK? I'll get a lift from somebody, I'll take a cab if I have to. Rose? You still there?
(strangely subdued) I'm still here.
Rose, tell me what's wrong. Please. I'm going crazy here.

I can't talk now. See you soon. Read is suddenly left holding a receiver humming a dial t He waits only a second or two before he starts to look frantically for the phone number of the Keloid Clinic in small book hanging from a nail by the phone.
(thumbing through the book) Christ! What was the number of that place?

Keloid is sitting at his desk in his bath-robe and slipp looking into a microscope holding a dry slide of Walsh's blood. There is a knock at his door. Keloid looks up as R enters, closing the door behind her.
Hi, Rita. I couldn't sleep. I've been trying to figure out what there could possibly be in Walsh's blood that would cause...
(interrupting with quiet urgency) Doctor, I think you'd better come with me.

A groggy Murray Cypher sits on a sofa in front of the TV in his living room, trying to get his four-month-old son drink his 6 a.m. bottle. The images of the early morning show -- the sound has been turned off -- seem to attract baby more than the bottle does. To Cypher's complete surprise, the telephone starts to ri YP. ip P

Oh, no. I just don't believe it. OK, Jeffrey -- you're on your own for a second. Cypher tries to prop the kid up between two cushions, but starts to cry the instant Cypher lets go of him. Cypher p him up and takes him over to the phone, which is on a she at the other end of the room.
No? You want in on the action? OK, let's go. Cypher picks up the phone.
(annoyed) What could you possibly want at this hour of the morning?
Murray, it's Hart Read. I hate like hell having to bother you like this, but I'm going out of my skull. It has to do with the clinic.
Yeah, OK. I was up anyway with the baby. So what gives?
I got this phone call from the clinic. From Rose.
From who?
From Rose. She's supposed to be ina coma. Keloid promised me he'd tell me the second she showed signs of consciousness and here I am getting a call from her at five in the morning.
Cypher is having trouble juggling the phone, the bottle, his baby, who is gumming the receiver and drooling into t little holes at the speaking end.
That is pretty weird. But maybe she came to in the middle of the night and didn't know where she was. Those things can happen. Jeffrey, don't eat the phone. You'll get indigestion.
But she said she was in trouble, Murray. She wants me to come and get her right now.
Look, Hart -- she's confused and she's scared. Did you phone the clinic  back and try to talk to Danny?
I did. I got to talk to a tape recorder. I left a message.

OK. I'll phone Danny right now at his private number, and I'll make sure that he knows that your Rosie is making phone calls in the middle of the night. Then I'll pick you up at your place in an hour and we'll go up to the clinic together. How's that grab ya?
Great. Phone me right back if there's a problem.
Absolutely.
OK, Murray. Thanks a hell of a lot. Read hangs up the phone. He takes a close look at one of pictures of himself and Rose on the Norton.

Rose sits quietly on the edge of her bed, her feet dangli over the side not quite touching the floor. She keeps her head down and does not look at Keloid, who is conferring with Rita at the door. Rita has given Rose a new gown and cleaned her up a bit for Keloid. Rita leaves and Keloid closes the door behind her. He tur to Rose and approaches the bed, tapping his stethoscope against the palm of one hand. He doesn't say anything unt he sits down on the bed beside her.

Rose... I'm Dr. Keloid. Dan Keloid. I'm here to help you, sweetheart. Rose lifts her head to look at Keloid for the first time Tears are streaming down her cheeks. She throws her arms around Keloid and begins to sob on his shoulder. Keloid h her gently and pets her on the head as though she were a child. After one or two moments, Keloid detaches himself from Ro and lies her back down on her bed.
Rose, we won't talk about anything right now except how you're feeling,
Rose nods, still snuffling slightly.

Good. First thing I want to do is to check out some of the skin grafts we did for you. Now, could you please just slip your arm out of your left shoulder strap and raise your arm over your head? Instead of doing as Keloid asks, Rose puts her hands over her face and shakes her head. Keloid is baffled.
What's the matter, Rose? Are you in pain? Talk to me, Rose. It's the only way I can understand what's bothering you.
(from behind her hands) I'm hideous, Doctor. I'm crazy and I'm a monster.

C'mon, Rose. There's just about nothing we can't fix if we know what's wrong. Now, I don't want any more games. Do what I tell you. Rose reluctantly takes her hands away from her face and s her left arm out of its shoulder strap. A pause, and then she raises her left arm above her head on the pillow.  Keloid can barely suppress his surprise at what he sees. Nestled in Rose's left armpit is a fleshy, tubular lump w an opening at the upper end of it. Keloid reaches over an presses it gently with his fingertips.
Does that hurt?

No. It doesn't hurt. Keloid takes a closer look at the fleshy pouch. The openi at the upper end seems to be surrounded by sphincter musc Keloid gently spreads the opening with his thumb. Deep wi the pouch, something an angry pink color, something glistening, seems to be pulsating. When he removes his th the muscles pull the opening closed again the way a draws closes a bag. Keloid sits up on the side of the bed again, trying to re his composure.

(after a pause) As far as I can tell now, it'll take just a very minor operation to remove that growth from under your arm. It may be some kind of external intestinal tissue. The neutral field tissue graft we did has been trying to find a way to get food that you can digest into your body. I was hoping it would do that by providing you with a regular set of small intestines but it seems to have had something different in mind. Rose shakes her head. A baffled expression comes over Kel face.
How long have you been conscious, Rose? Do you know?
Couple of days.
Do you feel weak?
I feel strong. I feel very strong.
Rita tells me you refused to let her attach you to your intravenous nutrient bottles. Why?
I don't need them. They make me feel sick.
I don't understand. They've got to be your only source of food.
They're not. They haven't been for a couple of days. Not since that man...
Man? What are you talking about?

I'll show you. Rose puts her right hand behind Keloid's head and draws i slowly down toward her left armpit. When Keloid's head is about a foot and a half away from the organ, Rose grabs K by the hair with both hands and strains upwards with her body. Keloid emits a low, gurgling scream which soon cuts off w the suddenness of a thrown switch. Exhausted of energy, K collapses across Rose, who begins to rock him gently from side to side as she pumps the blood from his body.

A battered old Ford pick-up truck pulls into the parking of a Colonel Sanders Kentucky Fried Chicken depot beside two-lane highway leading to the Keloid Clinic. The door o the truck opens and a vaguely familiar mangy dog jumps ou it belongs to the farmer who was Rose's third victim.

The farmer enters the take-out depot, which is deserted e for staff and one lone trucker. The farmer is wearing a of crooked and cracked sunglasses. He is not very steady his feet. His dog watches with concern through the glass door.
(to counter girl) One bucket of your best for me and my dog there.
Yes, sir. The counter girl conveys the order through the window int the kitchen, then turns back to write up the farmer's bil
Yes, and will that be... Oh! The girl's words trail off as she notices a tear of blood running down the farmer's cheek from under the right lens his sunglasses.
Hey, Mister. Did you know you're bleeding? The farmer dabs at his cheek with a tobacco-stained finge smearing the blood.
It's nothin'.
Musta had a rough night, Buddy.
Think I got in a fight or somethin'. Can't remember too good. The man in the kitchen slaps a bucket of chicken down on kitchen-window counter.
One bucket ready to go. The counter girl picks up the bucket and carries it over the trucker. She has just barely put it down when the far grabs it and starts tearing the lid from it.

Hey, Buddy. I think that one's mine. The farmer grabs a piece of fried chicken from the bucket and starts wolfing it down. The trucker puts his hand on farmer's shoulder and turns him around so that they face each other, a piece of chicken skin hanging from the farm lips.
I said... I think that one's mine, Buddy. The farmer starts shaking uncontrollably.
I gotta eat. I gotta eat. I gotta eat...

Take those glasses off so I can see who I'm talkin' to. The trucker reaches out and takes off the farmer's sungla To his disgust, he is confronted with one closed, swollen and bleeding eye, and one eye which has almost completely clouded over from white of eye to pupil.

What the hell... Bits of chicken drool from the farmer's mouth, followed b froth of dark green foam. Without warning, the farmer lun at the trucker and tries to bite his face. The trucker do out of the way, catches the farmer by his jacket and swin him over the counter, where he crashes into the counter g As the kitchen man comes out of the kitchen with a pot of boiling oil in his hand, the farmer grabs the girl and ma to bite her on the arm before she can pull away. Green fo dribbles into the girl's wound. Once the girl has pulled loose and backs away, screaming hysterically, the kitchen man throws the potful of oil on the farmer as he struggles to his feet. The farmer scream As the dog barks madly at the door, the trucker and the kitchen man jump on the farmer and pound him senseless be  the counter.

location: SURGICAL WASH-UP AT THE KELOID CLINIC

text: Keloid and Roxanne are preparing to perform an early morn facelift. They wash their hands and forearms and put on surgical gloves as the scrub-nurse prepares their masks a gowns. Keloid has a thick band-aid on his neck.
You're sure you want to do this one, Dan? Louise and I could handle it with no trouble.
I'll be fine.
You were pretty groggy this morning. (noticing band-aid Cut yourself shaving?

I'll be fine. Keloid turns away from Roxanne to avoid further discussio The orderly begins to help him on with his surgical gown. Keloid allows a pained, confused expression to take over face for a moment, then suppresses it.
On a six-lane highway leading out of Montreal, Cypher's station wagon starts out on its journey to the Keloid Cli
Inside, Cypher and Read sit bleary-eyed, both drinking co from styrofoam cups with slits in their covers and listen to the car radio in silence. The 8 a.m. news is in progre

...but there can be little doubt that the issue of police brutality will still be with us for some time to come. And speaking of brutality -- an incident of violence that took place over a Highway 11 fried chicken take-out counter ended in the death  of one man and the wounding of an eighteen-year-old girl. We'll give you further details on that story as they become available. Read and Cypher drive on to the sounds of a Radio Shack commercial.

Keloid, Roxanne, Karl, Louise, and the scrub-nurse are in the process of performing a routine facelift on a middle- aged woman. Roxanne watches Keloid closely for signs of fatigue as he makes the first cut under the woman's chin with a scalpel Keloid's hand is rock steady. He makes two more cuts and rolls back a flap of skin. Everything seems to be under control.
Cypher and Read drive on, listening to the rest of the ne story.

The man, later identified as forty- three-year-old Fred Atkins of Camelford, went berserk this morning during an argument over who was to be served his bucket of chicken first and bit the counter girl on the arm. The man was subdued by an unidentified truck driver and the chicken place's cook, but died of unknown causes before police arrived. Local health authorities suspect that rabies might be involved and have vaccinated everyone concerned. The dead man's dog was destroyed on the spot. And now, a brief pause for station identification, after which we'll talk to a scientist who says that earthquakes may one day become a thing of the past... While they listen to a variation of the Radio Shack commercial, Cypher notices that they're passing by the Kentucky Fried Chicken depot. There are still two police  cars parked in the parking lot.
Hey, we're right there.
(drowsy) Huh?
The place they were talking about on the radio. (joking) Wanna stop off for some fried chicken?

(not reacting to the joke) Not hungry, thanks. Cypher is about to say something further, but realizes th Read is too preoccupied with Rose to banter with. He deci to let it drop. They drive off to the sounds of easy-list radio.

Keloid is now stitching up the flap of skin under his patient's chin. Roxanne notices that his hand is no longe as steady as it was earlier on in the operation. He is ha trouble placing his stitches properly. His mask is soakin through at the mouth.
Do you want me to complete the stitching, Dr. Keloid?
I need... I need something to cut with, Dr. Rushton.
You want the scissors now, Doctor?
Yes. The scissors now. Roxanne's brow is furrowed as she reaches for the scissor on her instrument tray and hands them to Keloid.

Scissors. Instead of simply allowing the scissors to be placed in h hand, Keloid grabs Roxanne by the wrist with one hand and takes the scissors with the other. He turns to look at he She is shocked to see that his eyes have completely cloud over. Looking into them is like looking down two dark hol

Dan...! Without hesitation, Keloid takes the scissors and cuts th tip of Roxanne's index finger off. Roxanne stares down at her bleeding finger, an unvoiced scream rising in her thr Keloid lets the scissors drop to the floor and pulls down his mask. Dark green fluid foams from his mouth. He falls his knees and puts Roxanne's index finger in his mouth, sucking on it like a straw. Roxanne screams. Louise, who turned to look at Keloid at the sound of the falling scissors, screams in unison, backing away in terr and disbelief. The operating room explodes in confusion a panic as Keloid and Roxanne start to thrash about, knocki instruments and various surgical appliances to the floor. The patient slumbers on, oblivious. Dr. Karl, the anesthetist, leaves his post behind the patient's head and tries to pull Keloid off Roxanne.

Dan, don't be stupid! What's the matter with you? Are you crazy or something? Stop it! Stop it! Keloid lets go of Roxanne and sinks his teeth into Karl's shoulder. Karl screams in pain but doesn't let go. Louise finally regains enough presence of mind to run out of the operating room. Roxanne writhes in pain and shock on the floor.
I'm getting the police! I'm going to call the police!

Rose is sitting in the patients' lounge with one or two o patients, watching TV. Next to Rose is a mobile intraven cart, to whose three bottles she is attached by several I tubes. A young nurse we have not seen previously sits bes her, obviously instructed to keep a close watch on Rose, wears a clinic dressing-gown over her nightgown. Suddenly Louise comes flying past the lounge in hysterics half crying, half screaming.

(hysterical) He's gone crazy, he's gone crazy! He's killing everybody! There's blood everywhere! We've got to do something! We've got to get the police! She picks up a stream of staff members and patients who t after her trying to get some sense out of the completely distracted woman. The nurse watching Rose immediately get up and runs after Louise, as does one of the two patients watching TV in the lounge. The other patient, terrified b the panic in Louise's voice, shrinks into a corner and tr to look inconspicuous. The instant everyone rounds the corner at the end of the lounge, Rose stands up and pushes her IV cart down a hall that goes in the opposite direction.
Once she is out of sight, Rose quickly begins to detach herself from her IV tubes. Shouts and sounds of struggle rise and fall in the distance as she pulls the needles ou of her wrists.

Rose enters Judy Glasberg's room and closes the door behi her. She pauses only for a moment to glance at the photos Judy tacked up on the wall showing her before and after h proposed nose job, then opens Judy's closet and starts rummaging through the clothes hanging there.

Cypher and Read are on the last stretch of highway before the curve which reveals the driveway of the Keloid Clinic Read has not warmed up too much, his anxiety increasing a they've gotten closer to the clinic.
(looking through the windshield) Hey, look. What's going on there? The place is crawling with police.
What? Hey, you're right.
Oh, Christ, no! It's Rose. It's got to be. Something's happened to Rose!
Take it easy, Hart. They wouldn't need three cruisers for that. It's something else for sure.

Cypher's car pulls up the driveway, with Read hanging hal way out of the passenger door. Read jumps out before the has come to a full stop. There are indeed three Quebec Provincial Police cruisers parked at various strategic spots around the front of the clinic. There is also a paddy wagon parked right next to Quebec Bureau of Health van. Cypher and Read walk up to t front doors and enter the clinic.

Several police officers and a police photographer are mov through the building with Dr. Karl, who is describing wha happened to the officer in charge. Karl looks harried, confused, and very unhappy. Read and Cypher meet Karl and the head officer as they ta in the reception area. Karl's operating tunic is bloodsta at the shoulder.
(to Karl) Where's Dr. Keloid? What's happening?
Who are you?
Murray, thank God you're here. It's been a nightmare. (to cop) This is Murray Cypher. He's one of the owners of the clinic.
What's the story, Bill?
It's Danny. He went berserk in the middle of an operation. I was there. He tried to kill Roxanne. He cut her. They had to take her away. He chokes up.
(in disbelief) Danny? You've got to be kidding.
(to Karl) Oh, God. Have you seen Rose? Has anything happened to her? Is she all right?
Rose? You mean... no, no, this has nothing to do with her. She should be around somewhere.
(to Karl) OK, let's see if I've got this straight. You were in the middle of an operation, a routine facelift, did you say?

That's right. That's what we do here. The operation was just about over... it was Dr. Keloid who was performing it, you see... This is so bizarre... Read turns away from the main doors and walks through the reception area looking anxiously for Rose. There he encou two patients, Miss Owen and a slightly younger woman, sit  in lawn chairs discussing the events of the morning.
(to woman patient) ...certainly they took her away. She was bleeding and she was completely hysterical. Couldn't make out a word she was saying.
Have you seen Rose? The young girl who was in the motorcycle accident?
(confused) Do you mean the girl who was in here to have her nose fixed two times in a row...?
The chief cop, Cypher, and Karl are still talking.
(to Cypher) So you are in fact Dr. Keloid's business partner?
I am.
Come with me, please. The cop walks toward the main doors. Cypher turns to see Karl is going to follow. Karl shakes his head and looks d at his shoes.
I can't, Murray. You go. I've seen it. Baffled, Cypher follows the cop out the front door.

Cypher and the head cop leave the clinic and walk out to parking lot. As they pass the Bureau of Health van and th Keloid Clinic ambulance, Cypher sees a man in a medical uniform giving a police officer an injection straight in his stomach muscles in the ambulance. The officer's hand bandaged.
(to Cypher) Couple of my men got bitten. Those rabies shots are killers. Think I'd rather take my chances on getting sick instead.
Bitten? By what? They arrive at the back of the paddy wagon. The cop point to the mesh windows in the wagon's rear doors.

By that. Cypher looks through the mesh. Without warning, Keloid th himself against the mesh from the inside, frothing green the mouth, smeared with blood and moaning like a creature from hell. He tries savagely to bite Cypher through the w which cuts his lips and scrapes the enamel from his teeth Cypher jumps back.
Can you confirm the identification of this man as Dr. Daniel Keloid?
(totally dismayed) Oh, my God. My God.
Read approaches one of two police officers who stand talk to the police photographer.
Look... I'm trying to find my girlfriend. She's a patient here. She was here last night but nobody seems to have seen her.
We got a young girl downstairs. You wanna take a look at her?
Is her name Rose? The two cops look at each other, then turn back to Read.
We don't know. We didn't ask her. C'mon. (to third cop) Tell the chief I'm downstairs gettin' an ID. Be back in a flash. The third cop nods. Read follows the second cop down a hallway.

Read follows the second cop down the stairs leading to th clinic's basement, which still shows traces of the clinic origins as an old farmhouse. The second cop walks over to a bank of three huge upright freezers used to store the frozen food supplies for the clinic's staff and patients. Read hangs back and glances around the immense basement. The cop walks over to the farthest freezer and swings open the door.
C'mere. Can't see anything from there. Read approaches slowly, certain his worst fears are going be realized.

(gesturing toward the interior of the freezer) Is that Rose? Read forces himself to look. There, frozen into a block o ice that takes up the entire bottom of the freezer, is th hunched-over, naked body of Judy Glasberg, her eyes stari her lashes frosted, her mouth twisted horribly. Read exhales sharply, almost sobbing with a combination o horror and relief.
No. No, that's not Rose.

Rose is in the process of hitch-hiking her way into Montr She doesn't have to wait too long before an immense diese truck snorts and squeals to a stop on the gravel shoulder the road. Rose is wearing Judy Glasberg's jeans, boots, flannel shirt, and jacket. As Rose runs toward the truck, the passenger door swings open for her.

Rose sits in the passenger seat, her bare feet up on the dash tapping in time to the country-and-western music com from a tiny transistor radio hanging by a leather thong f the rear-view mirror. Rose is flushed and excited, almost delirious to find herself alive, healthy, and free. Beside her, the trucker eats a steak on a bun with great enthusiasm. He's in his forties, graying at the temples, gentlemanly. He's just about to start in on the second ha of his sandwich when he pauses and glances over at Rose, is happily watching the countryside rush by. The trucker holds out the second half of his sandwich to Rose, taking care to hold it in its tinfoil wrapper and not to touch i with his fingers.
Want this, Rose? Steak on a bun. Real good.
Um... wouldn't mind just one bite. She takes the sandwich, carefully peels back the tinfoil from one end, and bites into it. She chews and swallows.
You're right. It's fabulous.

The diesel truck pulls on to the dirt shoulder of the roa and comes to a halt. The passenger door swings open and R jumps down, stumbling as she hits the ground. She starts vomit before she even has a chance to get off her knees. The trucker comes around from the other side of the cab squats down beside her. He puts his arms around her and h her while she finishes being sick.

Last time I ever patronize that greasy spoon, I can promise you that. C'mon sweetheart. There's a girl. Get it all out. Rose wipes her mouth with the sleeve of her shirt and tri to stand up. She's still wobbly.

You just put your arms around me and I'll lift you back in. We'll get you some coffee or some soup or something at the next stop, OK? Rose nods weakly and puts her arms around the trucker. As lifts her up she holds him close and closes her eyes. A t runs down each cheek.
