Rose walks along the side of the road, hitch-hiking once again. After two cars pass her without stopping, an Ameri sedan pulls off the road slightly ahead of her and then b up to meet her. Rose gets in and the car pulls back on to the highway. She is flushed and invigorated.
Rose finds herself sitting next to a plump, pleasant-look lady in her late thirties who smokes a cigarette furiousl as she drives.
Hi. Where are you going?
Montreal. Where are you going?
Same place. Rose settles back in her seat and allows herself a smile Her cheeks are flushed and glowing.
That's wonderful. Thanks. I was beginning to think I'd never get back home again.

A Camelford police cruiser is on its way down the highway going in the direction opposite to Rose. We follow the cruiser down the road a few hundred yards u the diesel truck that stopped to pick up Rose comes into view, still stopped by the side of the road, its passenge door open. The cruiser pulls over and parks behind the truck. One of the QPP officers gets out and walks over to the cab of th truck. When he gets close to the cab, the officer finds t driver of the truck sitting sideways on the passenger sea his legs out of the cab, feet resting on the running boar The driver seems to be in some kind of daze and he is ver pale.
Something wrong?
Huh? Uh, no... nothing really wrong. I... I guess I musta dozed off. Yeah. That's it, I guess. Pulled over to have a nap.
Well, that's good. We find too many of you boys taking pills to keep yourselves going all day and all night. Next time, though, try to pick a better spot to pull over. This road's kind of narrow.
Oh, yeah. Right. Will do, Officer.
OK. Have a nice day.

Yeah. Thanks. As the trucker turns to watch the cop leave, we see blood trickling from a wound at the back of his neck which the trucker is obviously unaware of himself. The officer walk back to his car and waits until the truck pulls off the shoulder and heads back down the road toward the city.

The cruiser pulls into the parking lot of the local stati which is just off the two-lane highway between the clinic and the spot where the diesel truck stopped by the side o the road. In the parking lot, mixed in with various police vehicles are several familiar vehicles, including Cypher's station wagon and the clinic van. As the two officers get out of their car, they're met by Health Bureau official dressed in white who shows them hi ID card.
Claude Lapointe, Quebec Bureau of Health, official business. Sorry, boys. You can't go in unless you're willing to stay. The whole station's under quarantine. We think we've got an epidemic.

Inside the station, Cypher sits on one side of a desk explaining things to the head cop, who's trying to keep u with him on an old typewriter. Phones are ringing everywh typewriters are clacking away. In one corner we find Read glued to the receiver of a payphone, a finger in his free ear, trying desperately to hear what's being said at the other end of the line.

Hey, Mindy? You still there? Yeah, it's crazy here. I can hardly hear a thing. Yeah. Listen, I thought that Rose might try to get in touch with you. Yeah. She what? She called you?  Oh, that's great. She's on her way over? That's incredible. You wouldn't believe what's been happening. It's crazy time. Yeah. Totally. Well, listen. When she gets there, tell her I'll be stuck in the Camelford cop shop for at least forty-eight hours. Camelford. It's a town you go through on the way to the clinic. That's right. The whole clinic was hit with rabies or something, they're not sure exactly. Yeah, the whole clinic. She might have to come in for tests or something. I'll find out. Yeah. You keep her there for me. As soon as I get out I'll come and get her. Yeah. OK, Mindy. Ciao. Read hangs up. He discovers that he's actually smiling.
At a Montreal truck depot, crates are being unloaded from warehouse and on to a series of trucks. A dispatcher work his way through the crowd of loaders looking for a missin driver.
Hey, anybody here seen Eddy? He's got the lead truck and I can't find the son of a bitch. Hey, you seen Smooth Eddy?
I seen him climb into the box of his truck half an hour ago. He didn't look too good.
Whaddya mean he didn't look too good? Smooth Eddy always looks good.
Naw, I mean he looked sick. Like, nauseous.
What the fuck we runnin' here, a nursery? The dispatcher, a short, dark, mustachioed man, works hi way up to the lead truck.
Eddy... Hey, Eddy, you in there?
The dispatcher shoves his way to the sliding side door of Eddy's trailer and grabs the handle.

You in there, Eddy? We gotta get this rig movin'. The dispatcher slides the door open. Eddy screams the sec the light hits him and jumps out at the dispatcher, eyes clouded over, foaming mouth wide open. The dispatcher is bowled over by the force of the impact and he falls backw to the concrete, Eddy all over him, screaming and biting dispatcher's face and arms. In an instant five loaders are trying to pull Eddy away. Eddy immediately turns on them, managing to inflict sever bites before he disappears beneath the ever-increasing ma of loaders and truckers trying to get at him.

Mindy is watching TV in her cramped one-bedroom downtown high-rise apartment. Mindy is twenty-one, has lived on he own for years, is on the plump side of voluptuous, and wo for IBM selling office equipment. As she watches her color portable, Mindy idly turns the p of Vogue magazine, smokes a cigarette, and alternately si a cognac and a black coffee. There is a special newscast concerning the alleged rabies outbreak in the clinic regi complete with documentary footage shot outside the quaran QPP station.

...and health officials have said they consider the outbreak of the new strain of rabies as being potentially 'the worst of this century.' At the police station in Camelford, Kathy Draper talked to  Quebec Bureau of Health official Claude Lapointe. The news camera pans across the front of 52 station and e up in a close-up of Mr Lapointe, standing in front of his van.

Certainly this is serious. This is not just a question of swine flu or something like that. We have already several deaths on our hands in this one small area alone, and the main problem is... we don't know what we're up against.
Are you saying that this is not an outbreak of rabies?

I'm not saying that. I'm not saying that, exactly. But it must be a new strain of rabies, because there are symptoms involved which we and even the world health community do not seem to be familiar with.
What are these symptoms?

Well, the period of incubation of this disease is very brief, maybe six to eight hours at the most. Now, that's quick, much quicker than normal rabies. Then the victim begins to sweat, to shake, to foam at the mouth. That's not so rare. What is rare is that the victim always with disease becomes violent and bite somebody new. And this phase is followed by a coma in every case we know, It's very strange.
this new wants to crazy and then, by death. What advice would you give to our viewers?
The disease spreads through the saliva of the victim... the saliva is very contagious. It dribbles into open wounds and cuts and causes immediate infection.
So?

(shrugging) So... don't let anybody bite you. And if somebody does, find a doctor who can give you rabies shots immediately. We are already setting up vaccination centers beginning right here and spreading out toward Montreal. If we don't keep the disease localized and out of large centers of population, well... I wouldn't like to say what it could be like.
I heard you mention the Black Plague of London just before we went on the air. Is that what you mean by...?

(laughing) We sometimes like to be dramatic about these things. It's more interesting than the usual paperwork and we get... you know... we get excited. It's a real challenge... There is a knock at the door. Mindy gets up and opens it. Standing in the corridor is Rose.
Surprise. I'm amongst the living. Mindy throws her arms around Rose, hugs her, and pulls he inside the door. They separate, then hug again, both of t on the verge of tears.

Cypher and Read are sharing an open cell at the QPP stat which has been made as homely as possibly by the addition two chairs and a small table, which Cypher is using as a desk. Read lies back on the lower half of one of the cell three double bunk beds, arms behind his head, watching Cy sift through a maze of papers of all sizes and shapes.
Got anything in there I might want to read? I'm starting to go stir crazy already.
It's actually pretty exciting stuff if you know how to interpret it. Cypher throws down his Audit Point pen, leans back, and p his feet up on the table.
I guess I'm just going on automatic pilot right now.

(shakes his head) I can't connect that creature I saw in the paddy wagon with Danny. I just can't believe they're all dead... Read is on the verge of saying something when they are bo startled by the sound of a sudden chase in the main offic at the end of the row of cells. Screams and yells are punctuated by the crash of overturned furniture and smash glass. Read and Cypher barely have time to get to their feet whe they see the head cop backing slowly through the door lea to the main office, his service revolver drawn.

George, for God's sake! Can't you understand what I'm saying? Stay back! Sit on the floor and put your hands on your head. When the cop is about a third of the way down the aisle between the rows of cells, Read steps out behind him. The cop doesn't take his eyes away from the doorway.
What's going on?

Get into the cell and be ready to lock yourselves in. Do what I tell you! Before Read has a chance to move, a second cop appears, sweating, staggering, drooling green foam, eyes expressio black holes. The infected cop is stalking the head cop. Somebody shouts from somewhere back in the main office.
Get out of the line of fire, Ted. We'll take him from here with the scatterguns.
(shouting back) Gimme a count of three, Joe! I'll be outta your way by three!

One...! The head cop draws even with the door of Read and Cypher' cell. Cypher has already backed into it and flattened him against the wall opposite the aisle. The infected cop com closer. Cypher notices the bandage on his hand, then recognizes him as the cop at the clinic entrance who was bitten by Keloid and got rabies shots immediately afterwa
Two...!
(to Read and Cypher) Gimme room. I'm coming in quick.

Three...! The head cop dives sideways into the cell. The infected c lunges forwards after him and is half-way through the cel door when Read, hanging on to the bars of the cell for leverage, puts his foot in the cop's stomach and kicks hi back out into the line of fire. Before the infected cop c regain his balance, he is punched to the floor by several  shotgun blasts. By the time the guns stop firing, the infected cop's body has been pushed almost to the end of the aisle. The head steps out to meet the three cops from the main office, wh approach warily through the acrid smoke drifting up from barrels of their guns.

(to nobody in particular) They gave him rabies shots. He got bitten up at that facelift place and they gave him his shots right away. The head cop turns away from the body and looks up at the three men from the main office.
They didn't do him any damn good, did they? Read and Cypher exchange glances. It's been a lousy day.

Mindy and Rose are sitting in Mindy's living room, Rose i front of the TV on the sofa, Mindy at a small desk in the corner with papers and some sort of training manual sprea out in front of her. Rose is watching TV with a long ear plug trailing from the silent TV set across three feet of rug, up the sofa, and into her left ear. Rose is watching Shivers, starring Paul Hampton, Joe Silv and Barbara Steele, and is getting very restless. She can help glancing over at Mindy, who is eating a ham sandwich while she works. Mindy has her hair pulled back and the p in her neck is somehow very prominent. Rose pulls the plu out of her ear, turns off the TV set, stands up, and goes the closet next to the front door. Mindy looks up from he work for the first time.
What are you doing, Rose?
(putting on her jacket) I think I have to go out for a while.  Mindy gets up and joins Rose at the door.
Rosie, I feel so stupid. I haven't been much of a hostess. Why don't you stay here? There must be something in the fridge I can tempt you with.
(opening the door) Thanks, Mindy, but it's not that. I just have to get out into the fresh air again. It's a real experience for me just to walk down a street.
I'll come with you.
No. You stay here and work. I won't be gone too long.
OK, Rosie. If you get dizzy or anything, call me. Rose laughs, pats Mindy on the cheek, and leaves.

Rose walks down the most crowded part of St. Catherine's Street she can find. She has a new sensitivity to the hea radiating from the bodies of those close to her, and the presence of so much warm, jostling flesh full of blood wh coursing she can almost hear soon makes her eyes shine, h nostrils flare, her steps quick and precise. Rose soon finds herself standing in front of an Eve Cinem which is showing two soft-core skin flicks, as usual. On impulse, Rose digs around in the pockets of Judy Glasberg jeans. In the back pocket she finds a five-dollar bill. S hesitates for only a moment, then buys a ticket and enter the cinema.

Rose walks down the center aisle and sits alone in the mi of an empty row of seats not far from the screen and its murky orgiastics. It is not long before a thirtyish, balding man leaves hi seat at the back of the cinema and sits directly behind R As he removes his jacket, he brushes against Rose's hair with his hand as though by accident. Rose turns around to look at him.
"Scuse me. I didn't mean to touch you. Rose gives him a hard look, then turns around to face the screen again.
Well, pardon me for existing. Rose turns around again.
I thought you did it on purpose.
No. Really. I was taking my jacket off and it brushed against you.
Oh, well, I'm sorry. I like seeing these movies but men are always bothering me. I guess I'ma little paranoid.
Well, look. If I come and sit beside you everybody will think we're together and you'll be able to watch in peace. All I ask is a couple handfuls of popcorn.

(laughing) OK. C'mon. The balding man gets up, moves to the end of his aisle, t makes his way toward Rose, trying not to blow it by betra his excitement. He sits down beside Rose. She offers him some popcorn.

Rose slips out of the side exit of the cinema into an all her cheeks flushed, her breathing heavy. Crowds of people still throng past the opening at the end of the alley, th night just beginning. Rose watches them move past as thou still watching a movie, feeling the full weight of her separation from the ordinary. After a pause, she moves ou to join it.

Back in the theater, the balding man is still sitting in seat three rows from the screen, slumped down, his head o his chest, one arm thrown out around the edge of the seat beside him. Blood streams from a small hole in the palm o the outstretched hand, which is still curved as though embracing someone's shoulder. The images reflecting from the screen flicker across his face, but he sees nothing.
Mindy is preparing and eating her breakfast of bran muffi coffee, and orange juice on the run. While she shuffles h coffee cup and her notebooks, she listens to the radio.

...decide that each municipality should take on the responsibility for setting up vaccination centers in community halls and health clinics. Police have criticized the City Hall decision, saying that evidence has come to light which indicates that normal rabies vaccine is completely ineffective against the new strain of the disease. They are asking instead for the organization of a series of militia-and army-controlled quarantine centers until such time as an effective vaccine is developed. Said one police spokesman: 'We are having trouble containing the known outbreaks of violence induced by the disease as it is. Imagine what will happen if it spreads through the  city like a normal wave of the flu. Mindy has finally gotten herself ready to go to work. Jus before she leaves, she knocks on the bathroom door.
I'm going, Rosie. I've left you some coffee on the stove. Turn it off if you go out, OK?
OK. 'Bye.
(slightly worried pause) Aren't you going to wish me luck? (pause) Are you OK?
(oddly muffled) Brushing my teeth. Good luck.
(relaxing) Thanks. See you later. Mindy turns to the front door, opens it, and leaves.

In the bathroom, Rose is doubled over on the floor clutch her stomach. Two seconds after she hears the front door s closed, she lets out a low, strangled moan and begins to roll around on the floor. A sudden spasm forces her to curl into a ball again, her fingernails sinking into the palms of her hands. After th spasm passes, she props herself up against the bathroom d A thread of blood curls down her wrist. She opens her rig hand. She stares at the four tiny crescents of blood that her nails have cut into her palm. With slow, trancelike motions, she licks the blood off her wrist and her palm.

Mindy stands in a crowded subway station waiting for her train to come. Every once in a while she glances down at  marked page in a blue corporation manual she's carrying, checking her memory against the printed specifications of various pieces of office equipment. The train finally comes and Mindy gets crammed in with th rest of the rush-hour crowd.

As the subway car pulls out of the station, Mindy leans against the door and continues to consult her manual. As looks up and off into space, trying to grasp the next set machine specifications, her eye is caught by the face of woman with her back against the opposite door. The woman seems to be blind -- her eyes are completely black from e to edge. Then Mindy notices with horror that the woman is tremblin and drooling and foaming green at the mouth. The sea of f between them seems indifferent to the woman until she scr at the top of her lungs and plunges forward with her mout wide open, apparently trying to get at Mindy. The people closest to the woman suddenly start to panic, the panic moves out through the car in waves. Everyone st to push and shove, and people try to climb over one anoth The infected woman manages to lock her teeth on to the ea of a man who begins to punch her in the chest and stomach himself completely terrified. The subway car pulls into the next station and its doors open. Mindy is almost knocked to the platform and trample but she manages to stay on her feet and flow with the stampede. The people waiting to get on to the train are greeted wit the spectacle of three men subduing an insane, shrieking woman on the floor of the car.

Mr. Lapointe, Quebec Health Bureau official, is riding in the back of a city limousine with an official from the ma office. The limousine is working its way through the rubb of a deserted construction site.
(exasperated) You'll pardon me, Mr. Stasiuk, but I  think the mayor should be taking this epidemic more seriously than he is.

A city is a complex machine, Mr. Lapointe. Every part needs constant attention. The mayor will listen to you, but you're not the only one. It takes time... The limousine has worked its way into a relatively desert section of the site, and now slows to a stop.

(to uniformed driver) Why have we stopped, Clark? The driver points through the front windshield at the mannequin of a construction worker waving a flag that has been placed directly in the middle of the narrow dirt roa they're travelling on.

Well, isn't there anyone around? Do we have to turn around? Before anyone can make a move, two construction workers suddenly emerge from the surrounding rubble and advance o the car, one of them carrying a pneumatic jackhammer.

Clark... roll down your window and ask them why the road is blocked. It may be strike trouble. Be careful. Clark is in the process of rolling down his window when t man with the jackhammer turns on the hammer and applies t chisel to the driver's door. As the chisel point of the h chews up the door, Lapointe can see that the eyes of the workers are clouded over and that they are all slavering green foam from their mouths.
Oh, Christ! Clark, let's get out quick! Quick, man!

They've got the disease! Look at  their eyes! Report that to your mayor! Before the driver can slam the limousine into reverse, th second infected worker has reached through the window and grabbed him by the hair. The hammer has completely penetr the door. The driver screams. They'll kill us! The two workers begin to drag the screaming driver out of the car. The official scrambles over the front seatbacks into the driver's seat, kicks the legs of the driver away from the foot controls, and slams the gearshift into reve The limousine fishtails backwards madly as the official f the accelerator, the crumpled, bloodied driver's door fla like a broken wing as the car backs down the road. In the rapidly receding distance, Lapointe can see the infected workers hunching over Clark's body.

Rose sits in the middle of a shopping mall full of early Christmas shoppers. Her hair is matted and straggly and s watches the people in the mall hungrily. In the backgroun children line up to sit on the knee of a huge, enthroned Santa Claus surrounded by elaborately wrapped presents an Christmas trees attached to a huge backdrop of crimson an tinsel. Two cops, a nervous young cop carrying a submachine-gun, an older cop, watch the proceedings tensely. Large crowds always mean trouble. The two cops patrol the mall separat keeping in touch by radio. A pleasant young man stops in front of Rose's bench, looks her over, then decides to ge acquainted.
(to Rose) Mind if I sit down?
No. I don't mind. The young man sits down.
Nothing like Christmas, huh? Rose doesn't answer. The young man is running out of open lines.
Ah... you smoke? You know... cigarettes? You smoke?
Yeah. Sure.

Great. Have one of mine. The young man fumbles in his jacket pocket for his pack o cigarettes, then awkwardly shakes one out of the pack for Rose. She takes it. The young man puts one in his mouth, then starts to feel around in his pockets for matches. He can't find any.
No matches. You got a light? Rose shakes her head. The young man looks around. He spot man with a cigarette in his hand at the end of the adjace bench. He gets up.

Just a sec. I'll ask that guy over there for a light. OK? Be right back. He walks over to the man on the bench. As he approaches, notices that the man's cigarette has burned right down to the flesh of his fingers.

"Scuse me, Mac. Gotta light? Without warning, the man on the bench leaps up at the you man and grabs him by the hair. The man, a powerful, beard man of about sixty, has eyes like black holes and is droo green foam. He pulls the young man's head back and begins tear at his throat with nicotine-stained teeth. The young man screams. The two cops break into a run the instant they locate the source of the screams. When they arrive at the bench, the bearded man looks up, his beard and mouth stained with bl The young man is quite obviously on the verge of death. T young cop levels his submachine-gun at the man.

Stand up! Stand up and put your hands behind your head! The bearded man jumps up and tears off through the crowd incredulous onlookers. The young cop follows him. The bea man heads for the Santa Claus display.

Outta the way! Get outta the way. He'll kill you! That man'll kill you! The children around the Santa Claus display scatter as th bearded man heads for them. The Santa Claus stands up and grabs at the bearded man just as the young cop opens fire with his submachine-gun. His bullets rip through both men and the entire display, scattering bits of Christmas wrap and plastic fir trees everywhere. The older cop arrives on the scene, revolver drawn, just post-action shock hits the young cop.
Oh, Christ... I didn't mean to hit the Santa Claus. Deep in the gathering crowd, a traumatized Rose pushes he way through to an exit.

We are close on a TV set sitting on the admitting sergean desk just inside the station's main entrance. A detailed analysis of the disease crisis is in the process of being broadcast, complete with news footage of army and militia jumping off trucks in Place Ville Marie, citizens being vaccinated at community health centers and at emergency d set up in subway stations, etc.

...and the crisis has now been officially granted epidemic status by officials of the World Health Organization. The Prime Minister was reluctant to officially declare a state of emergency, but as any citizen in the streets can tell you, martial law has come to Montreal. At an emergency vaccination center set up  in the Atwater Metro Station, we spoke with a director of the World Health Organization who had just arrived from England to take charge of liaison with Health Bureaus in Western European countries. The face of an aristocratic and very tweedy Englishman ap on the screen with the name Dr. Royce Gentry, Director, W flashing beneath his face on the screen for a moment or t

I don't think there's any question that martial law is needed in the city of Montreal at this point in time. It's a necessity. It has already been established that victims of the disease -- and it is not rabies, though it may be related to the rabies virus -- victims of the disease are beyond medical help once it has established itself to the degree of inducing violent behavior.
What you're saying, then, Dr. Gentry, is that...

What I'm saying is very simple. It may not be very palatable for your viewers. Shooting down victims of the disease is as good a way of handling them as we've got. If we lock them up, they immediately go into a coma and die shortly afterwards. We've now got a vaccine that we think will work ina preventative way, but for those who are already incubating the disease... as far as we know, there's no hope for them. The face of Dr. Gentry is replaced by a close-up of a nee sinking into an arm.

All those receiving shots of the new vaccine are being issued plastic ID  cards with a photo of the card holder. Viewers are urged not to leave their homes unless absolutely necessary, and are reminded that if they do they must carry their vaccine cards with them. Police, army, and militia officers may demand to see them. Here is a list of vaccination centers in your area and the toll-free telephone number of our special emergency information center. Read and Cypher, rumpled and haggard, are signing forms a the main desk of the station prior to being released. Bot are wearing plastic vaccination plates on their jackets, Read toying impatiently with his.
(to desk sergeant) Goodbye, Sergeant. You've been a wonderful host.
OK, Murray. Take it easy. You sure you don't want to stay out here with us? The city doesn't sound like a very appetizing place to be.
I would, but my wife and kid... you know how it is.
(very twitchy) C'mon, Murray. Rose is waitin' for me.
OK, kid. Let's go.
Cypher and Read get into Cypher's station wagon, a QPP of handing Cypher the car keys as he gets in.

Remember to keep your windows up and your doors locked once you get into the city. Maybe the bug can't get  you now, but that... (tapping Cypher's plate) ...that won't protect you from the crazies. Take care now. Cypher nods and starts his car. They pull out of the park lot and on to the highway.

Rose lies curled up in Mindy's double bed, the blankets twisted up around her, sweating, her shoes still on, her muscles contracting with waves of spasms that roll over h Rose hardly notices the sound of keys jingling, the latch turning, the front door opening. Mindy's home.
(closing the door and locking it) Rose? Are you home? We hear the sound of Mindy walking through her living roo then approaching the bedroom.

Rose? Are you asleep? Mindy enters the bedroom, a bag of groceries in her arms. She stops at the door, shocked at Rose's appearance, then puts the bag down on her night table and sits on the bed beside Rose.
Have you been out? Have you gotten your shot? Rose rolls over to face Mindy. Her lips are pale and parc her nose is running, her voice shakes as she speaks.

(feebly) I... I've been afraid to go out. And, Mindy, I... I'm starving. I'm starving to death. And I don't want to eat. I don't want any more to eat. She bursts into tears and rolls away from Mindy, who sli across the bed after her and begins to stroke Rose's fore
Rosie, what's been going on? What's the matter with you? Poor kid. Well, don't worry any more. We're two tough ladies, you and me. We can handle anything we have to.

Read and Cypher descend into the city on a long expresswa ramp which affords them a clear view of other sections of highway and a large suburban plaza dominated by a huge supermarket. Both their ramp and the other sections of highway are str with wrecked and burned-out cars and even the occasional body. As the station wagon descends, they can see the line-up o people moving in and out of the supermarket guarded by soldiers with light machine-guns. Before anyone is allowe into the supermarket, he has to present his vaccine card a registration desk set up at the entrance. Cypher and Read plunge on, deeper into the city.

location: STREET AT FOOT OF EXIT RAMP

text: The station wagon swings off the exit ramp and on to a ci street, narrowly missing a few piles of garbage, which se to be everywhere. The street seems to be deserted, the stores on both sides closed and dark.

The station wagon turns on to a long, broad, practically deserted street. The only human activity is centered arou a convoy of heavy white city garbage trucks manned by whi uniformed, hooded figures. The convoy of twelve is led by military jeep whose rider, an army sergeant, orders them peel off one by one down specific routes deemed primary f decontamination. Armed soldiers ride on the tops of the trucks carrying r with telescopic sights.
I can't believe it. It's like we were at war.
Listen, Hart. We're going to my house first. I'm not going to relax until I know that everything there's OK. Once we're there, I'll give you the keys to the car and you can go get your girl.
(tense) OK. Thanks.

The station wagon pulls up into the driveway of Cypher's small but pleasant suburban house. Except for a bit of ga strewn about, there are no signs of unrest in the neighborhood. The odd rifle shot in the distance is fairl easy to ignore in these surroundings.
Cypher gets out of the car and Read slides over into the driver's seat.
Phone me when you get there, will you? Maybe you should bring Rose back here with you until this thing blows over.

Yeah. Listen, thanks for the car, Murray. I'll call you. Cypher smiles and heads up the driveway toward his front door. Read waits until Cypher has safely let himself into his house, then pulls out of the driveway and on to the street.
Cypher enters his house and closes the door behind him. H puts his briefcase down on top of the hall radiator and w toward the foot of the stairs.

Cecile? It's Murray, honey. I'm home. Nobody answers. Cypher resists the temptation to panic an walks through the downstairs rooms. Everything seems reasonably neat but there is no one there. Cypher returns the foot of the stairs and starts the climb to the second floor.
Cypher gets to the top of the stairs and begins to move a the narrow hall taking him to the front of the house.
Cecile? I'm home, honey. Where are you? Cypher stops at the doorway of the baby's room and looks

Cypher scans the baby's room, which from its cartoon wall to its brightly colored broadloom and toy-filled shelves speaks volumes about the fastidious preparation which pre baby's arrival. He is about to continue on down the hall to the master be when he notices that the broadloom beneath the baby's bathinette is wet. On an impulse he enters the room and l open the top covering the bathinette. The bathinette is h filled with bloody bath water, which has been leaking on the carpeting, drop by drop, for hours. Cypher lets the lid drop down with a mixture of fear and horror suddenly stabbing him in the pit of the stomach. A insane kind of moaning giggle drifts over to him from the corner of the room. He whirls to face the sound. It seems to be coming from t closet. Drawn inexorably toward the sound, he approaches closet, which is not completely closed. He raises his han  to grasp the doorknob. Without warning, the closet door explodes open, smashing Cypher in the face and knocking him to the floor. A craze drooling Cecile lands heavily on top of him and begins to bite him savagely on the face, her clouded eyes devoid of all mercy or recognition.
Mindy has tucked Rose into bed and is now applying a cold compress to her feverish forehead. Rose seems to be half asleep.
That's it, Rosie. You just get as much sleep as you need. Don't think about anything. Let your mind drift. Mindy gets up and goes into her kitchen, leaving Rose's d open just a crack.

In her kitchen, Mindy continues preparing an elaborate vegetable stew, somehow convinced that her weeks in the hospital have induced in Rose an aversion to meat. The TV set, Mindy's constant companion, has been turned a so that Mindy can just see it from where she's working, although the sound has been turned off in deference to Ro At the moment there seems to be a detailed analysis of th difference between rabies and the new strain of disease holding the city in thrall, complete with microphotograph in progress.
Rose takes the compress from her forehead and places it carefully on the night table. She slips out of bed and be to rummage around in the closet for her clothes.

Read drives Cypher's station wagon along a downtown stree on his way to Mindy's. There are more people on this particular street than the ones he and Cypher first encountered. In fact, were it not for the heavily armed soldiers placed at several strategic points and the singl  guarded garbage truck making its rounds, all would seem normal. The sound of sporadic gunfire in the distance see to have been accepted as everyday fare by everybody. But Read's focus of attention is on the car radio. He has been listening to an analysis of the possible origins of disease and the information he's getting is disturbing hi The voice on the radio is that of Dr. Royce Gentry.
And so after using some rather elaborate tracking procedures and applying them to a map, we find that the disease does in fact seem to have a very specific place of origin.
Which is...?

Which is the Keloid Clinic of Cosmetic Surgery, a few miles outside the town of Camelford. You can see with your own eyes how everything has spread out from there in geometrically increasing proportions. Now this pattern, in conjunction with some of our other statistics, indicates that there is a strong possibility that there is a special factor at work in the spread of the disease.
You mean a carrier.
Well, at the risk of setting off a futile witch hunt... Yes. Someone like the infamous Typhoid Mary who incubates the disease and transmits it, but is herself immune to it.
What were they doing at the Keloid Clinic, Dr. Gentry?

We've run into a certain amount of difficulty ascertaining what exactly  was going on there. We know what it wasn't. It had nothing to do with germ warfare or the like... no secret government contracts... Read's concentration is suddenly shattered by a movement catches in the corner of his rear-view mirror as he waits for a light to change. A crazy -- a man in his forties we a scarf and gloves but no coat -- breaks out from between two buildings just behind Read's car and heads for the clusters of people crossing at the light. Read watches the man brush by the car as though watching scene on television. The people in the crosswalk scatter the crazy's approach. The sniper on top of the garbage tr has him safely in his crosshairs and squeezes off a shot. The crazy hurtles against the hood of the station wagon a though falling from a building and bounces off and on to road. Before Read can drive off, two garbage men run toward him from the garbage truck. One of them holds up his hand for Read to wait. He produces a spray bottle from under his w jumpsuit and sprays the crazy's blood that has spattered car's hood. Then he waves Read on. Read puts his windshie wipers on.
Rose is dressed and trying to steal out the front door wh Mindy hears her from the kitchen.
Rose? Are you awake? Rose yanks open the door and has one foot out the door wh Mindy appears around the corner with a dish of sauce in h hand.

Oh, no. Rose! You can't! It's dangerous out there! Mindy bangs the plate down on top of a stereo speaker and runs after Rose. She catches her a few steps out the door and hauls her back inside, swinging the door shut again w her foot. The door doesn't lock. Rose is whimpering and weak. She starts to sink to the fl and Mindy, not strong enough to hold her up, goes with h
Mindy, Mindy. I don't want it to be you. Mindy hugs Rose tightly, rocking her back and forth.
Of course it should be me. Who else but your best friend, Rose? I'll take care of you.
(pause) Oh, Mindy, I ache all over. I'm hurting from the inside out.
Well then, what you need is a nice, deep, hot bath. It'll seep in and relax you from the outside in. She starts to unbutton Rose's shirt. Rose doesn't resist.
Read parks the station wagon in front of Mindy's building and gets out. He sprints up the front steps.

Read emerges from the elevator at the end of the corridor and walks purposefully past the row of doors until he rea Mindy's. He reaches for the door. He notices that it's ajar and pu back his hand at the last minute. He takes a deep breath, then kicks open the door.

As the front door of Mindy's apartment slams open, Read i confronted by the bizarre spectacle of Rose hunched over Mindy's prostrate form, sucking blood from the large vein one of Mindy's arms. The instant the door slams open, Rose pulls her blood-suc organ out of Mindy's arm and tries to hide it with her ri hand. The organ, still dripping blood, slides back up un her arm into its sheath. The half-conscious Mindy puts he hand over the hole in her arm and mumbles incoherently. As Read approaches, Rose backs away, slipping her left ar back into her shirt and fumbling with the buttons. Rose n looks flushed and healthy, excited and alive.
(quietly) It's not my fault. It's not my fault.
It's you. You're the one. It's been you all along.
What are you talking about?
You carry the plague. You've killed hundreds of people.
No... no... you don't know what you're talking about. I'm still me. I'm still Rose.
What did they do to you at the clinic? What did they turn you into?

(suddenly angry) I have to have blood. It's all I can eat. And it's your fault, not mine. It's your fault! Read takes three quick steps and grabs Rose by the should She shrinks away from him as though he were the monster.

There must be some way to fix this... We'll go to the police... we'll go to the hospital... Rose twists out of Read's grasp and runs for the front do Read turns and runs after her, almost tripping over Mindy Rose makes it out the door before Read can catch her.
Read chases Rose down the corridor.
Rose, I'm sorry... wait! Wait!
Read finally manages to catch Rose at the top of the stairwell. They struggle.

Rose, listen to me. You're right. We're in it together. We'll figure it all out together... As they struggle, Rose somehow smashes Read in the face w her elbow and he goes crashing backwards down the flight stairs, hitting his head several times on the metal steps he goes. She watches in horror as Read falls, then stands frozen f several heartbeats after he has landed in a crumpled heap the bottom of the stairs. She runs down after him and kne beside him. He has a few large bruises on his forehead and temples bu is still breathing. Rose touches his lips with her finger briefly, then gets up and continues down the stairs.

Rose opens the front door of the apartment building and s out on to the front steps, bewildered. There she sees a m with a mustache sifting through a handful of letters on t bottom step. He looks up at the sound of the door opening
Can I help you? I've seen you around before, haven't I? I just moved out of this building. They keep sending my mail here.
I... yes, I'm a friend of Mindy Kent. I was supposed to meet her here, but she must have gone out.

Well, it's not safe to walk the streets these days, not for a while, anyway. Can I escort you somewhere? Have you been vaccinated? No? Me neither. My brother told me he had to line up for three hours. Who's got time?
Listen... I need a place to stay tonight. At least until Mindy shows up. Could I stay with you? For a little while?
(slightly flustered) I, ah... guess you could. I'm a single guy, you know. We'd be alone. (pause) That doesn't bother you? Rose shakes her head, wide-eyed and innocent.
I'm a nice guy, too. C'mon. My car's just down the street.
Night has fallen over Mindy's apartment and the streets a dark and completely deserted.

Read is only now regaining consciousness in the damp apar stairwell. He rubs his neck and gradually manages to get his feet. The top of the stairs looks as though it's a mi away. Read begins to climb the stairs, one painful step a time.
As Read staggers down the corridor, he hears a telephone begin to ring in the distance. The ringing gets louder an somehow, more persistent as he gets closer to Mindy's doo

The telephone is patiently ringing in Mindy's apartment, though waiting for Read to answer it. He enters the apart and takes a quick look around for signs of Mindy. The pla is empty. He swings the door shut and locks it. Only then does he turn to the phone. Read answers the telephone.
Hello?

Rose has locked herself into the single man's apartment a slid a heavy table across the door. The single man sits slumped in an old wingback chair, his cheek bloody, his e closed. Rose has turned out all the lights in the apartment excep for a small mood light near the telephone, which sits on end table by a Victorian velvet sofa. She speaks quietly into the receiver, as though not wanting to wake the mustachioed man.
It's me, Hart. I'm glad I managed to get you. Are you all right? Did I hurt you?
Rose, where are you? We should be together. Please, tell me where you are.

Well, what you said to me hurt me. It scared me. It scared me because I suddenly knew you might be right. And if you were right, about my being a carrier, I mean... then I... I murdered Mindy. I murdered a lot of people.
Rose, listen to me... No court of law would convict you...
So I decided to try a little experiment to prove that you were wrong about all that. You see? I'm being very positive, aren't I?
There's no reason for you to put yourself through anything like this...

So I found myself a partner for my experiment, a single guy, real normal and real healthy, and I took a little of his blood... just a bit... and I've locked myself in with him. And I'm going to stay here with him until I'm sure he's not going to get sick. And then I'll know that I'm not the one who started it all.
Rose, you've got to tell me where you are. You're committing suicide.
Hart, I just want you to be with me over the phone... just until I find out one way or the other. We can live together over the phone for a while. We can do that, can't we?
Oh, God. Rose, how long ago did you... take blood from the man you're with? How long ago?
Six hours. Maybe seven.
Rose, you've got to get out of there.
As Read talks, Rose hears a sound behind her. She turns t see a shadow rising out of the chair behind her. The sha seems immense.

Please, Rose, just drop the phone and walk over to the door and run outta that place as fast as you can. You're not giving either of us a chance to think. We don't need this pressure... everything's so confused... We've got to just clear a space where we can be alone and sit down and talk about everything and figure out what to do... Rose? Get out of there, get out right now! The shadow approaches Rose, who lies as still as death on the sofa. The single man is finally caught by the edge of the mood light's glow, and Rose can see the dead black ey the drooling green saliva, the slack, hungry lips.
Hart... I'm afraid! The single man lunges for Rose's throat.
Read screams into the phone.

Rose! Rose! He is in agony as he hears the sounds of Rose being torn apart at the other end of the line, but he is unable to t the receiver away from his ear, unable to desert Rose in final moments. He screams insanely into the phone, this t incoherently, trying to make it stop, trying to cover it But it doesn't stop.
In the chill of early morning, an armed garbage truck mov through the city collecting bodies left in the aftermath the night's anonymous violence.

On Mindy's street, just a few blocks away from Mindy's apartment, a garbage truck stops to collect a body covere with dried blood that has been dragged out on to the fron steps of an apartment building. Before the garbage men ca get the body, the sniper on the roof has to shoot a dog w is sniffing at the body. The garbage men are then able to get to the body, spray i with disinfectant, spray the dog's body, and drag them ba to the truck's compressor. As the body is dumped into the back of the truck, we see that it is possibly Rose's.
